sk1C3eML.title: Flexural subsidence by 29 Ma on the NE edge of Tibet from the magnetostratigraphy of Linxia Basin, China
sk1C3eML.abstract: This study provides a detailed magnetostratigraphic record of subsidence in the Linxia Basin, documenting a 27 Myr long sedimentary record from the northeastern edge of the Tibetan Plateau. Deposition in the Linxia Basin began at ∼29 Ma and continued nearly uninterruptedly until ∼1.7 Ma. Increasing rates of subsidence between 29 and 6 Ma in the Linxia Basin suggest deposition in the foredeep portion of a flexural basin and constrain the timing of shortening in the northeastern margin of the plateau to Late Oligocene–Late Miocene time. By Late Miocene–Early Pliocene time, a decrease in subsidence rates in the Linxia Basin associated with thrust faulting and a ∼10° clockwise rotation in the basin indicates that the deformation front of the Tibetan plateau had propagated into the currently deforming region northeast of the plateau.

FSnoQLPt.title: Structure and photoluminescence evolution of nanodots during pyrolysis of citric acid: from molecular nanoclusters to carbogenic nanoparticles
FSnoQLPt.abstract: Citric-acid-derived carbon nanodots are increasingly being explored as novel fluorescent nanomaterials due to their strong photoluminescence (PL). However, an accurate picture of the formation of carbon nanodots and an exhaustive structure–property correlation are still lacking. Herein we present a systematic investigation of the formation mechanism of carbon nanodots by following the pyrolysis of a citric acid–diethylenetriamine precursor at different temperatures. The collective nanodots are investigated by dynamic rheological measurements, exhibiting a strong pyrolytic temperature dependence of the viscoelastic properties. Atomic force microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and Raman spectroscopy reveal that the synthesized “dots” at different pyrolytic temperatures are different in essence, and the transition of their chemical structure from molecular clusters to carbogenic nanoparticles during pyrolysis is highly verified. We find that a molecular fluorophore with intense PL predominates at low temperature (u003c250 °C), but a newly created quasi-molecular fluorophore with blue-shifted and decreased PL quantum yield predominates at high temperatures (300 °C). Time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy suggests that the strong PL suppression at high temperature is due mostly to a dramatic increase in the nonradiative decay rate of the quasi-molecular electronic state.

bu4unBVp.title: Magneto- and litho-stratigraphic records of the Oligocene-Early Miocene climatic changes from deep drilling in the Linxia Basin, Northeast Tibetan Plateau
bu4unBVp.abstract: Abstract   The East Asian monsoon is generally regarded to have initiated at the transition from the Late Oligocene to the Early Miocene. However, little is known about this process because of a lack of continuous strata across the boundary between the Late Oligocene and the Early Miocene in Asia. Based on previous drilling (core HZ-1) in the Miocene sediments in the southern Linxia Basin in NW China, we drilled a new 620 m core (HZ-2) into the Late Oligocene strata and obtained 206 m of continuous new core. The detailed paleomagnetism of the new core reveals eleven pairs of normal and reversed polarity zones that can be readily correlated with chrons 6Bn-9n of the geomagnetic polarity time scale (GPTS), define an age interval of 21.6–26.5 Ma and indicate continuity from the Late Oligocene to Early Miocene. The core is characterized by the remarkable occurrence of brownish-red paleosols of luvic cambisols (brown to luvic drab soils) above reddish-brown floodplain siltstones and mudstones, which suggest that the East Asian monsoon likely began by 26.5 Ma. In contrast to the siltstone and mudstone of the Late Oligocene strata, the Miocene strata begin with a thick fine sandstone bed, which marks sudden increases in erosion and loading that most likely reflect a response to tectonic uplift. The hematite content and redness index records of the core further demonstrate that the monsoonal climate in the Late Oligocene to Early Miocene in this area was mainly controlled by global temperature trends and events.

nX37kW1h.title: Timing and provenance of loess in the Sichuan Basin, southwestern China
nX37kW1h.abstract: Loess-like sediments (locally called the Chengdu Clay) are widely distributed in the Sichuan Basin, at the eastern margin of the Tibetan Plateau (TP), southwest China. Geomorphology, sedimentology/pedology, grain size distributions and quartz oxygen isotopic ratios collectively demonstrate the aeolian origin of the Chengdu Clay and its main source area on the TP. Evidence also supports its transport by the Westerlies and the Tibetan winter monsoon. The magnetostratigraphy of the Huagai loess section of the Chengdu Clay (on the highest river terrace of the Anchang He River) indicates that the sediments began accumulating at about 825 ka BP. This suggests the establishment of a circulation system similar to the present-day system related to the rapid uplift of the TP at that time.

3s839gMW.title: One-pot synthesis of 3,5-disubstituted 1,2,4-thiadiazoles from nitriles and thioamides via I 2 -mediated oxidative formation of an N-S bond.
3s839gMW.abstract: A simple and practical method for I2-mediated one-pot synthesis of 3-alkyl-5-aryl-1,2,4-thiadiazoles has been developed; the one-pot reaction includes sequential intermolecular addition of thioamides to nitriles, and intramolecular oxidative coupling of N-H and S-H bonds mediated by molecular iodine. Meanwhile the protocol uses readily available nitriles and thioamides as the starting materials, molecular iodine as the oxidant, and generates various 1,2,4-thiadiazoles in moderate to good yields with a wide array of functional groups. This method is an efficient approach for the synthesis of unsymmetrically disubstituted 1,2,4-thiadiazoles.

S00jrWj0.title: Clinical observation on efficacy of gemcitabine combined with carboplatin in treating the senile patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer
S00jrWj0.abstract: Objective To investigate the efficacy and side effects of combined chemotherapy based on gemcitabine in treatment of the aged with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer(NSCLC).Methods Fifty patients in this study were divided into monotherapy group(30 patients)and combined therapy group(20 patients).Those in monotherapy group were given gemcitabine 1200 mg/m2 on the first day and eighth day,and those in combined therapy group received gemcitabine 1200 mg/m2 on the first day and eighth day and carboplatin 300 mg/m2 on the second day.All the drugs were given intravenously.The efficacy and adverse effects were evaluated according to WHO Standard after 3 cycles of treatment.Results The response rate of montherapy group was 26.7%(8/30)and that of the combined therapy group was 55.0%(11/20),the difference was significant(P<0.05).The incidence of adverse effects was higher in the combined therapy group(P<0.01).The major toxic reaction was bone marrow depression.Conclusion The toxic reactions of monotherapy with gemcitabine is mild,which improves the safety of medication and the quality of life in aged patients.

rpTn7VeB.title: Iodine-125 implantation combined with chemotherapy of GP regimens for non-small cell lung cancer in elder patients
rpTn7VeB.abstract: Objective: To evaluate the feasibility, safety and curative effect of radioactive particle 125 I combined with GP in treating NSCLC. Methods: Among 40 NSCLC cases, we did primary treatment in 24 cases, and secondary treatment in 16 cases. During the process, all the patients were embedded 125 I particles into tumors under the guidance of CT, then treated with GP 3-5 days later(GP: GEM 1 000 mg/m 2, intravenous dripping in 30 minutes, on the 1st, 8th, 15th day; DDP 30 mg/m 2, intravenous dripping, on the 1st, 2nd, 3rd day; with 28 days as one cycle, altogether 2-4 cycles). Two months after embedding the particle 125 I into the tumors (i.e. after 2 chemotherapeutics cycles), the evaluation of short term efficacy and adverse effects were carried out. Results: Two months after embedding the particle 125 I into the tumors, all the 40 cases showed curative effects including CR in 9 cases, PR in 23, SD in 5 and PD in 3 with total effective rate of 80.0%. In the primary treatment group, there were CR in 6 cases, PR in 14, SD in 3 and PD in 1 with effective rate of 83.3%. In the secondary treatment group, there were CR in 3 cases, PR in 9, SD in 2, PD in 2 with effective rate of 75.0%; showing no remarkable difference between the two groups (P > 0.05). Conclusions: The chemotherapeutic embedding radioactive particle 125 I combined with GP is safe, feasible, and effective to the therapy of senile-inoperable NSCLC.

H2nx2lBo.title: Polymorphism of Partial Sequence of the Porcine CACNA1S Gene and Its Association with Meat Quality Traits
H2nx2lBo.abstract: Single-nucleotide polymorphism of CACNA1S gene of 30 Suzhong pigs and 97 F2 offspring of Jinhua and Pietran pigs was analyzed by polymerase chain reaction-single strand conformational polymorphism(PCR-SSCP),and its association analysis with meat quality traits was conducted.In results,25 mutations were found in 1 234 bp of CACNA1S gene.It was observed by association analysis that the AA and BB genotypes of primer 1S-65 had significant effects on ham weight(P<0.05),the AB genotype of primer 1S-65 had significant effects on ham pH(P<0.05),and the BB and BC genotype of primer 1S-66 showed the most significant effects on hoofs weight(P<0.01).

PEBPEe8A.title: Sedimentology, sedimentary petrology, and paleoecology of the monsoon-driven, fluvio-lacustrine Zhada Basin, SW-Tibet
PEBPEe8A.abstract: In this paper we present sedimentologic, petrographic, and paleoecologic data from a ~ 810-m-thick section of late Neogene (ca. 9–7 to 1 Ma) fluvio-lacustrine deposits in the high-elevation Zhada Basin of SW-Tibet. The tectonic evolution of the Zhada Basin region, located between the Himalayan Mountains in the S and the Transhimalayan Mountains in the N, is poorly understood, but sediment accumulation was probably initiated in response to the middle/late Miocene uplift of the Gurla Mandhata and Leo Pargil domes in the E and W, respectively. The sedimentary record can be subdivided into five stratigraphic units with distinctly different lithofacies associations (LA); these are, from bottom to top: a bedload-dominated fluvial LA (Unit 1, 0–90 m); a nearshore lacustrine, deltaic LA (Unit 2, 90–220 m); an offshore lacustrine LA (Unit 3, 220–500 m); a nearshore lacustrine, fan-delta LA (Unit 4, 500–600 m); and a fan-delta/alluvial fan LA (Unit 5, 600–810 m). Clast and heavy mineral compositions revealed sediment supply from two different provenance areas, one from the south and one from the north/east, based on catchment geology of the Himalaya and Transhimalaya. Ostracode faunal assemblages are largely comparable to those of modern Tibetan lakes and allow the reconstruction of paleo-lake environments, including lake-level changes and salinity. The sedimentary pattern shows strong cyclicity at various scales (m, 10 s m, and >100 m). Small-scale cycles are interpreted as intrinsically-controlled depositional processes of deltas (lobe switching), whereas medium- and large-scale cycles are most likely forced by climate fluctuations. The overall evolution of the sedimentologic record includes: a strong and rapid increase in fluvial discharge in the uppermost portion of Unit 1, a transition from fluvial to lacustrine deposition during deposition of Unit 2, rhythmic variations in the style of lacustrine sedimentation during deposition of Unit 3, an increase in the supply of coarse clastics starting with deposition of Unit 4, and a transition from lacustrine to alluvial sedimentation during deposition of Unit 5. We speculate that the increase in discharge and, presumably, precipitation leading to the establishment of lacustrine conditions in the lower part of the section (Unit 2) is largely due to regional summer monsoon intensification during the late Miocene, and that the transition from lacustrine to alluvial sedimentation in the uppper part of the section reflects the onset of Northern Hemisphere glaciation and winter monsoon strengthening at ~ 2.6 Ma. Keywords Zhada Basin Tibetan Plateau Monsoon Fluvio-lacustrine sedimentology Sedimentary petrology Ostracodes 1 Introduction The evolution of the Asian monsoon climate is important for our understanding of regional- to global-scale paleoclimate, but is still poorly understood. Early hypotheses on the evolution of the monsoon system assumed that conditions similar to present-day had been established at ~ 8 Ma. This was based on evidence for a drastic increase in aridity in the Himalayan foreland of NW-Pakistan ( Flynn and Jacobs, 1982; Barry et al., 1982, 1985; Quade et al., 1989 ), and for monsoon-induced upwelling in marine deposits of the Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea ( Kroon et al., 1991; Nigrini, 1991; Prell and Kutzbach, 1992 ) at that time. In the context of the «gravitational collapse» model, these changes were interpreted as the consequence of substantial surface uplift of the Tibetan plateau preceding the ~ 8 Ma initiation of E–W extension in southern Tibet ( Pan and Kidd, 1992; Harrison et al., 1995 ). Subsequently, however, several lines of evidence have questioned this simple picture. For example, significant E–W extension in central Tibet started at least ~ 14 Myr ago ( Blisniuk et al., 2001 ), and paleoelevation estimates based on leaf physiognomies imply that at least the southern part of the plateau was at elevations similar to today's by ~ 15 Ma ( Spicer et al., 2003 ). Moreover, it has become increasingly evident that the monsoon system was initiated much earlier than 8 Myr ago. For example, recent studies infer the presence of a monsoon climate since at least ~ 22 Ma based on a study of eolian deposits exposed NE of the Tibetan Plateau ( Guo et al., 2002 ), since at least ~ 15.5 Ma based on changes in clay mineralogy observed in sediment cores from the South China Sea ( Clift et al., 2002 ), and since ~ 12 Ma based on oxygen isotope values of authigenic carbonate in fluvial and lacustrine sediments of the Linxia Basin NE of Tibet ( Dettman et al., 2003 ). It also has been demonstrated that the post-8 Ma evolution of the monsoon climate has been much more complex than previously thought. Based on records of eolian sediments from China and marine sediments from the Indian and North Pacific Oceans, An et al. (2001) inferred three stages of evolution of Asian climates: (1) enhanced aridity in the Asian interior and onset of the Indian and East Asian monsoons, about 9–8 Ma; (2) further intensification of the east Asian summer and winter monsoons, together with increased dust transport to the North Pacific Ocean, about 3.6–2.6 Ma; and (3) increased variability and possible weakening of the Indian and East Asian summer monsoons but continued strengthening of the East Asian winter monsoon since about 2.6 Ma. This is in good agreement with the results of a sedimentological study of ≤8.35 Ma eolian deposits in northern China, which suggest that the East Asian winter monsoon was characterized by (1) gradually strengthening from ca. 8–6 Ma, followed by weakening between 5 Ma and 3.5 Ma, (2) marked monsoon strengthening beginning between 3.5 Ma and 3.1 Ma, and (3) further monsoon strengthening after 2.6 Ma ( Qiang et al., 2001 ). However, a severe limitation of monsoon climate reconstructions is that, while several marine and terrestrial long-term climate records are available from sites near the Himalaya–Tibet orogen, there is no such record available from a high-elevation site within the orogen. Our work in the Zhada Basin, which contains a thick sequence of late Neogene fluvial and lacustrine deposits, is part of an effort to establish a long-term climate record in this region. In this paper, we present (1) sedimentologic and petrologic data to reconstruct sedimentary facies, provenance, and weathering conditions, and (2) ecologic data from ostracode species assemblages that allow us to infer paleoenvironmental conditions during deposition of these sediments. 2 Geologic setting The ~ 10,000 km 2 area of the Zhada Basin is located at ~ 80°E between the Himalayan and Transhimalayan Ranges to the S and N, and the Gurla Mandhata and Leo Pargil domes to the E and W, respectively ( Fig. 1 ). The southern and northern boundaries of the basin roughly coincide with the South Tibetan Detachment System (STDS; Burchfiel et al., 1992 ) and the Great Counter thrust (e.g., Yin and Harrison, 2000 ). None of these structures has been studied in detail in the direct vicinity of the Zhada Basin, but both are continuous along most of the Himalayan chain, and tectonic activity along them is generally thought to have pre-dated deposition of the Zhada Basin sediments. The main phase of activity along the STDS has been estimated at 24–16 Ma (e.g., Hodges et al., 1992; Guillot et al., 1994; Harrison et al., 1995; Hodges et al., 1996; Searle et al., 1997; Dezes et al., 1999 ), with relatively minor localized brittle reactivation (e.g., Vannay and Hodges, 1996; Hodges et al., 1998; Hurtado et al., 2001 ). The chronology of movement on the Great Counter Thrust is more poorly constrained, to between 20 and 4 Ma in the Kailas region ( Yin et al., 1999 ), and between 19 and 10 Ma in more eastern portions of the orogen ( Quidelleur et al., 1997 ). The main tectonic control on the basin formation presumably was uplift of the Gurla Mandhata and Leo Pargil domes, which was initiated ~ 9 Myr ago at Gurla Mandhata ( Murphy et al., 2002 ), and probably around the same time at Leo Pargil ( Thiede et al., 2006 ). The Zhada Basin has been the subject of few previous geologic studies; however, the results of these have shown that the basin contains a ~ 800 m-thick sequence of predominantly lacustrine sediments with fluvial intervals at the base and top, and limited biostratigraphic and magnetostratigraphic data suggest a ca. 7–1 Ma age range for these deposits ( Zhang et al., 1981; Qian, 1999 ). Based on biostratigraphic and magnetostratigraphic data, the age range of these deposits has variably been estimated as ca. 7–1 Ma ( Qian, 1999 ), 9.5–2.6 Ma ( Wang et al., 2008a ), and ca. 9–1 Ma ( Saylor et al., 2009 ). In this paper, we describe a ~ 810 m-thick composite section which covers most of the Zhada Basin stratigraphy; the basal strata in our lowermost sub-section can be traced to a locality a few km farther west, where they are underlain by ca. 20–25 m-thick gravels that lie unconformably on Mesozoic limestones. Due to post-depositional erosion of the Zhada Basin strata, outcrops of the oldest deposits are found at well-exposed cliffs along the deeply incised Sutlej River Valley, whereas the youngest portions of the section are exposed closer to the basin margin in the south. Accordingly, the composite section ranges from a more basin-central setting at the base to a more marginal (southwestern) setting towards the top. We did not observe any tectonic features except for a few normal faults with a typical offset of ca. 0.1–2 m, oriented 040/70 to 070/70 (dip direction/dip) and thus slightly oblique to the Karakorum fault system to the north. 3 Methods To investigate the sedimentology, sedimentary petrology, and micropaleontology of the Zhada Basin deposits, we obtained a composite section of basin-central to south-marginal Zhada Basin deposits ( Figs. 1 and 2 ) by detailed logging and lateral correlation of thirteen individual sub-sections. The sub-sections are distributed along a N–S trending line ( Fig. 2 ) with a lateral distance of ≤1 km between the individual sub-sections. Excellent exposure, almost perfectly horizontal bedding, and high lateral continuity of the sediments facilitated the lateral correlation between the sub-sections. Lateral correlation was typically carried out by physical tracing of marker beds and the use of survey level, altimeter, and photo panels ( Fig. 2 ). Sedimentological logging was carried out at a cm- to dm-scale within marly and sandy units, and at a dm- to m-scale within thicker gravel units. Paleocurrent directions were measured throughout the entire section in ripple cross-laminated and cross-bedded sands, and cross-bedded or imbricated gravels. Gravels and sands were sampled for clast and heavy mineral analysis. Gravel deposits were investigated for clast composition and maximum clast size, and clast counts were carried out every ca. 50–100 m where gravel deposits were available. At each site, we counted 100–120 clasts and grouped them into 10 lithotypes (see below). Sand samples were sieved and ca. 5 g of the 0.06–0.3 mm size fraction were used for heavy mineral separation. 100 grains of each separated heavy mineral sample were picked, classified, and counted by Dr. Maria Mange (UC Davis/USA). Marl samples collected for paleontologic analyses (ostracodes) were washed, sieved, and dried; ostracode shells were hand-picked, counted, and classified. Habitats were reconstructed according to those of modern Lake Nam Co ostracode species. About 75 ostracode-samples have been analyzed for paleoecology so far. 4 Results 4.1 Sedimentology: description and interpretation of lithofacies The composite Zhada section ( Figs. 2 and 3 ) comprises variable proportions of siliciclastic and carbonate sediment. The lower- and uppermost parts of the section are dominated by coarse clastics (mostly gravel and coarse sand). The middle part is dominated by finely laminated and thick successions of mm- to >15 m-thick marlstones, often forming steep cliffs, and interbedded with mostly medium to coarse sands. The clastic sediments are largely unconsolidated with the exception of common occurrences of cm-thick cemented sandstones. The section can be divided into five distinct units representing different lithofacies associations based on lithology, sedimentary structures, sedimentary architecture, and lateral continuity ( Figs. 2 and 3 ). From bottom to top (with stratigraphic levels given in meters from the base of the measured section), these are: Unit 1 (0–90 m), fluvial gravels and sands; Unit 2 (90–220 m), deltaic sands and marlstones; Unit 3 (220–500 m), lacustrine-dominated sands and marlstones; Unit 4 (500–600 m), massflow-dominated deltaic gravels, sands and marlstones; Unit 5 (600–810 m), alluvial fan and fan-delta gravels. Our description and interpretation of these lithofacies associations can be summarized as follows: 4.1.1 Unit 1: Fluvial gravels and sands [0–90 m] The basal portion of the measured section comprises ca. 30 m-thick gravel and coarse sand deposits exposed along a steep cliff at the southern side of the modern Sutlej River Valley ( Fig. 2 ); these deposits can be laterally traced to a locality several km farther W, where they overlie another 20–25 m of similar coarse clastics that onlap onto Mesozoic basement (Jurassic limestone). The basal coarse clastics in the section consist of gravel (<8 cm in diameter, locally imbricated) and coarse, often pebbly sand interbedded at a m-scale ( Fig. 4 A ). These deposits contain abundant internal bedding structures like m-scale channelized cross-bedding, horizontal stratification, and dm-scale planar and trough cross-bedding. Gravel and sand form amalgamated units a few m to <10 m thick and show a moderate fining-upward grain-size trend. The bases of individual depositional units are commonly gravelly (gravel lags, pebbly sand) and sharp and slightly erosional. Massive or laminated fine-grained deposits, i.e. clay, silt and very fine sand, are usually a few dm to <4 m thick where present. The colors are gray to dark-gray, yellowish-brown, and rarely mauve. Root traces and, more commonly, plant debris and gastropod shells occur. Ripple cross-lamination is rare in fine sand layers. The fluvial succession terminates with a ca. 10 m-thick gravel sheet (clasts 10 cm in diameter) that can be laterally traced along the Sutlej River Valley for >2 km. The gravel sheet has a 2–3 m deep erosional base, and this channelized structure is filled with m-scale cross-bedded gravel beds. 4.1.2 Interpretation of Unit 1: bedload-dominated fluvial lithofacies association Rare large-scale, steeply dipping (>20°) trough cross-bedding suggests that the majority of the coarse fluvial sediments can be interpreted as channel-fill deposits. Deep erosion (up to 2 m) is uncommon, but rare intraformational mud clasts (up to >10 cm diameter) indicate erosion of nearby floodplain fines. Sheetflood deposits cannot be excluded; however, the coarse sands and gravels are commonly cross-bedded. The mauve color of some of these fine-grained sediments and the presence of few rootlets suggest weak paleosol formation, although evidence for well-developed pedogenesis has not been observed within these deposits. Trough cross-bedded sands and gravels were probably deposited within channels, whereas planar cross-bedded sands and gravels are more likely the result of migrating sand bars. Based on the depositional style, these bedload-dominated, fluvial deposits are interpreted to have formed in a gravelly braided-river system (after Miall, 1996 ). The development towards a more distal (or lateral) fluvial facies associated with less and finer sediment supply and a more stable, aggrading floodplain is suggested by decreasing bed thickness, clast- and grain-size, and thicker and more abundant overbank deposits upsection. Indicated by a reversed grain-size trend higher up, the fluvial style seems to have developed into a sandy-braided type (after Miall, 1996 ) with more stable channels. The recurrence of coarse, thick gravels at the top of this unit may be the result of intensified discharge, and the fluvial plain later transformed into a large lake system. 4.1.3 Unit 2: deltaic sands and marlstones [90–220 m] This unit is composed of mostly medium to coarse sands and interbedded sandy and silty marlstones with widespread soft-sediment deformation features ( Fig. 4 B). The marl content increases upsection, while the coarse clastic content decreases successively. The base of Unit 2 is marked by a matrix-supported gravel bed (ca. 20–40 cm thick), which directly overlies the gravel sheet on top of the preceding fluvial Unit 1; this extensive gravel bed can be traced laterally over a distance of >2 km. Above, coarse-grained pebbly sands grade upwards into finer-grained deposits including an increasing number of silty to fine sandy marlstones. The trough and rarely planar cross-bedded medium to coarse, rarely pebbly sands are similar to the fluvial sands below. The sands show both fining- and coarsening-upward trends. Above ca. 110 m, silty to fine sandy, gray to dark-gray massive marlstones, a few dm thick, are commonly interbedded with these sands. Marlstones and fine sands contain plant debris as well as rare rootlets and burrows. Wave ripple cross-lamination and soft-sediment deformation features include slumps and water (or gas) escape and load structures ( Fig. 4 B). Moreover, abundant gastropod shells characterize horizons within gray to dark-gray silt and fine sand beds. Shallow (<20 cm) stacked sandy channel-fills are common. Low-angle, large-scale cross-bedding is observed in medium to coarse (pebbly) sand above ~ 120 m, associated with climbing ripple cross-lamination, rootlets, burrows and soft-sediment deformation features. Channel-fill deposits of coarse to pebbly sand with set thicknesses of 0.5–1.0 m, and thin (mm-cm) sheet-like laminated, mostly graded medium to coarse sands are also present. From 90 m on upwards, iron oxide crusts generally separate marlstones from sands with a very thin (commonly <1 mm, rarely >2 mm), sharp contact, even in strongly deformed sequences. 4.1.4 Interpretation of Unit 2: nearshore lacustrine (deltaic) lithofacies association The matrix-supported gravel bed at the base of this unit is interpreted as debris flow deposit blanketing a «drowning» fluvial plain. Overlying trough cross-bedded coarse, pebbly sands (90–110 m; Fig. 3 ) were probably deposited in interdistributary channels by bedload-dominated subaerial to subaqueous currents of a fluvial-dominated delta-plain (e.g., Elliott, 1986, 1989 ); remnants of fossil wood, common in these deposits, are characteristic for such a deltaic setting. Thin, massive silty marlstones with shell fragments that formed on top of these coarse sediments are interpreted as marsh deposits on the delta-plain (e.g., Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992 ). Higher up in the section (110–220 m), the interbedded siliciclastic and marlstone deposits were presumably formed in subaqueous delta-front and prodelta-slope environments (e.g., Elliott, 1989; Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992 ). Trough and planar cross-bedded medium to coarse sand beds with rare marlstone intraclasts are interpreted as mouth-bar deposits formed on the proximal delta-front. Rare channel-fill deposits ( Fig. 4 B) were deposited in distributary channels of the delta-front. Beds characterized by soft-sediment deformation formed on the proximal slopes of the delta-front, where sediment supply was highest and may have exceeded the stability of the inclined delta-front slopes ( Fig. 4 B; see, e.g., Moretti and Sabato, 2007 ). Sands containing burrows and plant debris are interpreted as subaqueous levee and crevasse splay deposits of interdistributary bays near distributary channels. Ostracode assemblages (see below) are predominantly composed of shallow-water species, which supports the interpretation of a delta-plain. The low-angle, large-scale (swaley) cross-bedding at ca. 120–160 m is interpreted as hummocky cross-stratification (HCS). In combination with associated wave ripple cross-lamination, these structures suggest lacustrine conditions above the storm wave base (e.g., Eyles and Clark, 1986; Dumas and Arnott, 2006 ), similar to a shallow marine lower shoreface environment ( Walker and Plint, 1992 ). The HCS structures and the very common reworking by wave activity suggest a strong influence of wind ( Horton and Schmitt, 1996; Blair and McPherson, 2008 ) and thus indicate common storm activity during this depositional interval in the Zhada Basin; this may be already a signal of monsoon activity (e.g., Quade et al., 1989; An et al., 2001 ). The graded, parallel laminated sands alternating with marlstones can be interpreted as turbiditic sands of a distal delta-front or prodelta-slope far from river entry points into the lake. Overall, its sedimentologic characteristics imply that Unit 2 represents the transition from fluvial to lacustrine facies. A delta-plain developed above the thick gravel unit at 80–90 m, consisting of coarse, trough cross-bedded interdistributary channel-fill deposits that are frequently topped by thin, finer-grained marly or silty marsh deposits. Delta-front deposits include here mouth-bar and distributary channel complexes, as well as interdistributary bay deposits and levees (e.g., Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992 ). These delta-front deposits formed laterally persistent (for several 100 m) sand bodies, on average a few meters thick. This suggests deposition over a wide area with several distributary channels rather than in front of single, isolated channels. Sediment supply was probably very high as suggested by the predominant coarse sands and comparably little fine-grained clastics of associated marshes. The topography of the lake margin was probably characterized by a very gentle slope; steeply inclined Gilbert-type prodelta foreset beds (e.g., Elliot, 1978; Schaad et al., 1992; Fernández and Guerra-Merchán, 1996; Blair and McPherson, 2008 ) were not observed. Furthermore, the typical deltaic coarsening-upwards «parasequence» is here only rarely observed (e.g., at 180–190 m), suggesting a rapidly retreating shoreline and thus a rapid expansion of the lake. The prodelta-slope consists of turbiditic graded sand sheets. This deltaic sedimentary architecture corresponds to the type-C distributary system of Postma (1990) . An increasing marl content upsection signals [a] the establishment of a large, deeper lake and [b] the widening of the lake area towards the Zhada Basin margin. Paleocurrent measurements show a northward-directed sediment transport ( Fig. 3 ) with a relatively high scatter (from WNW to ENE) indicating that the sediment source was predominantly located in the south. 4.1.5 Unit 3: lacustrine sands and marlstones [220–500 m] Unit 3, representing the central part of the Zhada section between ca. 220–500 m ( Fig. 5 A ), is largely characterized by alternating clastic and calcareous units. The sands, generally interbedded with thin marlstone layers, are typically composed of one to several m-thick, rarely channelized beds, often with sharp bases and tops. They are mostly trough cross-bedded and ripple cross-laminated, especially in the higher parts of Unit 3. The up to 20 m–thick marlstone units have varying siliciclastic contents, frequently with increasing or decreasing grain-size trends at a dm- to m-scale. Characteristic sedimentological features include fine, mm-scale lamination, varying abundance of organic matter like plant debris, common gastropod shells, and rare bones from fish and land mammals (pers. comm. Xiaomin Wang, Natural History Museum Los Angeles County, 2006). In the uppermost part of the section, above 410 m, coarsening-upwards sand units become more dominant, and dm-thick gravel beds at 455 and 480 m indicate an overall increase in grain size ( Fig. 3 ) and thus proximity to the ancient lake shoreline. The alternation of sands and marlstones at m- to dm-scale in Unit 3 forms a repeated pattern. 4.1.6 Interpretation of Unit 3: offshore lacustrine lithofacies association The marlstone-dominated Unit 3, comprising the most distal (central) part of the studied section, is assigned to a prodelta to offshore environment where laminated marls were deposited below the storm wave base ( Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992 ). Clastic input is indicated by the abundance of more or less silty and very fine sandy detritus in the marl. Well-defined and laterally persistent sand units are regularly intercalated, suggesting cyclic turbidity current activity throughout the time of deposition. The commonly graded sand units usually follow a progradational (coarsening-upwards) to retrogradational (fining-upwards) supply pattern, indicating high sediment supply to the lake basin. The rare presence of wave ripple cross-laminated sands suggests sedimentation above the storm wave base and therefore a decreasing lake level. Thus, the turbiditic sands may represent lake-level lowstand deposits, whereas the thick marlstones were formed during high lake levels (e.g., Coe, 2003 ). The alternating sands and marlstones at m- to dm-scale indicate short-term fluctuations of the lake level. Since the sands appear and disappear in a gradational way, they may possibly point towards climatic signals rather than towards tectonic pulses. Above ca. 410 m, thicker sand units developed, showing low-angle swaley cross-stratification (HCS), indicating deposition above the storm wave base (e.g., Dumas and Arnott, 2006 ). Thus, the depositional style between 410–500 m changes from quiet distal slope/offshore conditions towards a shallower, storm-influenced environment. There, the coarsening-upwards sands are topped by laminated marlstones resembling a typical prograding, shallowing-upwards deltaic «parasequence» with an abrupt flooding and deepening on top, probably caused by abandonment of distributary channels ( Coe, 2003 ). Interestingly, >15 m-thick monotonous marlstones with very few sandy interbeds observed at ca. 235–265 m indicate that the most distal (deepest?) offshore conditions already occurred relatively early during the deposition of Unit 3. This, in turn, implies that the widening and deepening of the lake basin occurred relatively fast. From 265 m upwards, clastic sediment is rhythmically supplied and the vertical extent of the offshore marlstone units becomes more and more reduced. No significant sediment transport direction can be assigned to Unit 3 since nearly all possible directions were measured ( Fig. 3 ); however, a weak predominance of NE–SW oriented directions may reflect a predominant basin-axial sediment transport. 4.1.7 Unit 4: mass flow-dominated deltaic sands and marlstones [500–600 m] Unit 4 consists of ~ 2–15 m-thick clastic sediments, mostly gravel and sand, alternating with marlstones of variable siliciclastic content ( Fig. 5 B). The thick clastic beds contain gravels with ≤10 cm diameter clasts. Among the coarse clastic sediments, many gravel beds are matrix-supported. Soft-sediment deformation is a common feature in all sediment types of Unit 4. Coarse- and medium-grained sands are commonly cross-bedded and rarely contain burrows; silty and fine-grained sandy marls are commonly finely ripple cross-laminated with abundant root traces and rare plant debris. Wave ripples occur sporadically higher up in this unit. Typically, the sediments show coarsening-upward sequences of several meters thickness with coarsest gravels at the top. Laminated and often argillaceous marlstones are abundant but never reach a thickness of more than a few meters; they abruptly formed on top of the thick clastic sequences. In contrast to the underlying lacustrine Unit 3, storm deposits are absent. No paleocurrent directions were observed in this part of the section. 4.1.8 Interpretation of Unit 4: nearshore lacustrine (fan-delta) lithofacies association The numerous m-scale coarsening-upwards sequences are interpreted as progradational fan-delta lobes of one or more fan-delta systems. These progradational prodelta-slope to delta-front sequences are typically associated with gravel sedimentation indicating a nearby alluvial fan or alluvial plain. However, there is no indication of subaerial exposure. The matrix-supported gravels are interpreted as sediment gravity deposits (mass flows). Soft-sediment deformation is similarly abundant as in Unit 2 (90–220 m). These gravels were deposited on the proximal prodelta-slope, indicating high sediment supply and a less stable and probably steeper slope. Individual fan-delta lobes are typically several meters thick and show a «classic» coarsening-upwards development (e.g., Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992; Fernández and Guerra-Merchán, 1996; Clevis et al., 2004 ) from distal marlstones into proximal coarse sands or gravels; laminated marls cap each individual lobe. This termination of coarse sediment deposition of individual lobes and the recurrence of deeper lacustrine marls is either due to the abandonment of distributary channels, or to lake-level changes, i.e., representing lacustrine transgressive surfaces (e.g., Coe, 2003 ). Cap carbonates containing stromatolites have been observed in other nearshore lacustrine environments and were interpreted as precipitates during low-energy, quiet-water conditions ( Horton and Schmitt, 1996 ). However, based on ostracode data (see below chapter 4.3), shallow-water conditions can here be ruled out. At a larger scale (tens of meters), these m-scale coarsening-upwards fan-delta lobes form stacked, progradational coarsening- or fining-upwards depositional sequences representing prograding or retrograding alluvial fan systems. This larger-scale depositional development is best documented in the grain-size distribution of the clasts ( Fig. 3 ). 4.1.9 Unit 5: fan-delta and alluvial fan gravels [600–810 m] In the uppermost portion of the Zhada section, thick and massive gravel beds become increasingly dominant, and clast sizes largely increase upsection (30 cm at maximum; Figs. 3 and 6 ). Three different kinds of gravel deposits are present here. [1] The first type comprises faint, horizontally bedded, clast-supported gravels with abundant clast imbrication. This first gravel type is composed of amalgamated, >10 m-thick gravel units that consist of 0.5–1.0 m-thick individual sheets. The clasts are significantly smaller than in type-2 gravels (see below) and faint horizontal bedding is visible. The bases are only weakly erosional or non-erosional, and elongated clasts are commonly imbricated. [2] The second type is represented by massive, often channelized, upwards-fining and clast-supported gravels. It is characterized by the largest clasts, very poor sorting, and the almost complete absence of bedding structures. Channelized bases are common and there is sometimes a crude but well-defined fining-upwards trend towards the top of these gravels. In some of these massive gravels, m-scale soft-sediment deformation structures occur. [3] The third type consists of dm- to m-thick matrix-supported gravels. The matrix is typically medium to coarse sand, and the base of these gravels is mostly non-erosional. Interbedded with these gravels are thinner (m-scale) sequences of fine- to medium-grained sands and marlstones with variable clastic contents. The sands are typically trough cross-bedded and can have a channelized base. Other sedimentary structures include horizontal lamination, and wave and current ripple cross-lamination. Marlstones are often silty or sandy, laminated, rarely massive, and may even include pebble layers. Plant detritus and root traces are common; burrows and slumps are less abundant. 4.1.10 Interpretation of Unit 5: fan-delta/alluvial fan lithofacies association Gravel beds of type [1] are interpreted as sheetflood deposits that formed during flooding events on an alluvial fan (after Blair and McPherson, 1994 ); this gravel type formed subaerially. Gravels of type [2] represent either subaerial, channel-confined flow deposits of an alluvial fan or delta-plain, or subaqueous channel-fill deposits of a proximal distributary channel (e.g., Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992 ). Fine-grained deposits on top of these gravels either document waning stages of floods on a fan or represent shallow lacustrine deposits near the outlet of a tributary channel; this may be indicated by wave ripple cross-lamination. Type [3] gravels are typical gravity-driven mass flow deposits (e.g., Horton and Schmitt, 1996 ) that were possibly generated at the unstable slope of the proximal delta front near the tributary channel-outlet. The fine-grained (sandy–pebbly) channelized interbedded lithofacies probably represent distributary channel-fill or mouth-bar deposits, while the non-erosional, mostly upwards-coarsening laminated and massive sands are interpreted as progradational fan-delta lobe deposits (e.g., Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992 ). Abundant wave ripple cross-lamination emphasizes the importance of wave action in the shallow-water environment of the delta front. Steep large-scale cross-bedding typical of Gilbert-type delta-front slopes has not been observed. The potential of wind-induced reworking of slope deposits as an important control on fan delta architecture (e.g., the destruction of large-scale foreset beds) was pointed out by Blair and McPherson (2008) . Abundant slumping features and deformed gravel beds during soft-sediment movement may also indicate a somewhat steeper slope angle and thus a steeper basin margin in this uppermost part of the Zhada section, as compared to Unit 2 (90–220 m). The sediments of Unit 5 are interpreted to reflect alternating lacustrine and alluvial environments of the delta-front (slope), delta-plain and alluvial fan ( Fig. 6 ). Delta-fan lobe progradation is seen in the coarsening-upwards grain-size trends. The often abrupt onset of marly lacustrine deposition was most probably due to channel abandonment/lobe switching of a tributary of the alluvial fan, and to lake-level rise/flooding (e.g., Coe, 2003 ), similar to Unit 4 (500–600 m). This landward coastline shift caused trapping of sediment close to the lake margin and inhibited its dispersal on top of the former delta sediments. The formation of carbonate due to petrographic changes in the source area, as pointed out by Jiang et al. (2007) , is probably less important here since we see no significant increase in carbonate, neither in the clast assemblages ( Fig. 3 ), nor in the composition of the sands. The Zhada section terminates with a thick succession of terrestrial, sheetflood-type gravels that show a general upward decrease in grain size (from 30 cm to <15 cm; Fig. 3 ). Paleocurrent directions inferred from imbricated clasts show a radial, N- to E-directed drainage pattern that further supports the interpretation of an alluvial fan depositional environment ( Fig. 3 ). A delta-type-classification is difficult based on limited lateral facies information; however, features such as common wave ripple cross-lamination and hummocky cross-stratification imply phases of strong wave influence. Since large-scale foreset beds of Gilbert-type deltas are absent, the delta-type described here can be sedimentologically classified as «gravel-dominated, shallow-water mouth-bar-type delta» ( Nemec, 1990; Postma, 1990 ). However, evidence for abundant gravity-driven mass transport indicates that somewhat steeper slope angles may have existed in the upper part of the section. 4.2 Sedimentary petrology: clast analysis, heavy minerals The petrologic composition of the Zhada Basin sediments along with numerous paleocurrrent measurements provides an excellent database for characterizing the petrology of the catchment area (e.g. Kempf et al., 1999; von Eynatten, 2003 ). Moreover, petrologic data also may provide valuable information on possible environmental changes, especially on changing weathering conditions during the time of deposition ( Mange and Maurer, 1992 ). We have therefore analyzed heavy mineral assemblages from sands and carried out clast counts of gravel beds throughout the studied Zhada section ( Fig. 3 ). 4.2.1 Clast analysis The distribution of gravel beds throughout the studied section is highly variable. Gravels occur within the basal ca. 90 m, are absent until ca. 450 m, and increasingly abundant from ca. 450 m to the top of the studied section ( Fig. 3 ); the coarsest clasts were observed above 650 m. Gravel beds in the lower part of the Zhada section (0–90 m) are dominated by sand and limestone as well as chert; granite, gneiss, and quartzite clasts are also common, as are clasts of volcanic (rhyolite) and ultramafic (serpentinite) rocks ( Fig. 3 ). Based on both catchment geology and paleocurrent measurements, these basal clasts were derived from northern and eastern sources (i.e., the Transhimalayan Mountains). Gravel beds in the upper part of the Zhada section (450–650 m) are dominated by granite, gneiss, and quartzite clasts, while sandstone and limestone clasts are much less abundant ( Fig. 3 ). Near the top of the section, above ca. 650 m, this petrographic trend reverses to more abundant sedimentary clasts. Shists are relatively rare but have been observed throughout the upper part of the section. As indicated by the paleocurrent measurements, these clasts were derived from a southern/southeastern source (i.e., from the High Himalayas). Based on the clast compositions of the gravel beds, we distinguish two different provenance areas: a northern/eastern source area located in the Transhimalayan Mountains (SW of the line Gar–Songsha–Darchen, Fig. 1 ) which include the Indus suture zone with associated ophiolites, crystalline basement, and volcanic rocks, and a southern/southeastern source area situated in the partly metamorphic rock units of the High Himalayas ( Figs. 1 and 3 ). 4.2.2 Heavy minerals In addition to the clast compositions we also investigated the heavy mineral assemblages of the sands ( Fig. 3 ) to be able to relate the clast-free middle part of the section (90–450 m) to possible provenance areas. The resulting heavy mineral suites revealed at least two different compositions and support therefore the recognition of the two different provenance areas. Samples taken from above ca. 450 m, presumably derived from a southerly source, are dominated by a suite of ultra-stable heavy minerals (>75%; zircon, tourmaline, rutile). A similar composition of samples taken between 100–250 m suggests a similar provenance area, which is supported by the paleocurrent data from this stratigraphic interval. This source area is characterized by Precambrian–Mesozoic metasedimentary quarzites, limestones, shales, and metamorphic crystalline rocks of Greater Himalaya. Samples attributed to northern and eastern provenance areas contain variable but generally considerable amounts of relatively unstable heavy minerals (up to >70%; amphibole, tremolite, pyroxene, vesuvianite, serpentinite). The source area is composed of Paleozoic–Mesozoic metasedimentary rocks (see above), ultramafic rocks, and Mesozoic–Cenozoic intrusive rocks. Sediment supply from N to NE is documented in paleocurrent directions of the basal 100 m; in the middle part of the section, however, paleocurrent data do not indicate sediment contribution from north/east but suggest sediment transport along the basin axis (ca. NW–SE), possibly caused by turbiditic currents and/or strong winds. The two clearly differing heavy mineral assemblages represent provenance signals of the different catchment areas. In addition, the very high amounts of unstable heavy minerals below 100 m and at ~ 250–450 m may point towards less intense weathering conditions (e.g., Mange and Maurer, 1992; Dill, 1995 ). However, without additional knowledge on other weathering-sensitive minerals, such as clay minerals (e.g., Yuretich et al., 1999; Gibson et al., 2000; Suresh et al., 2004 ), this aspect remains speculative at this point. 4.3 Paleoecology: ostracode faunal assemblages Ostracode species assemblages, intraspecific morphological variability, and geochemical analysis of shell chemistry may provide information on past lake levels, salinity and water chemistry, temperature, habitat structure, oxygen concentration, biologic productivity and other environmental factors ( Carbonel et al., 1988; Delorme, 1989; Boomer et al., 2003; Holmes, 2008; Mischke et al., 2008; Holmes et al., 2009 ). Diatoms were not preserved in the sediments (pers. comm. A. Lotter, Utrecht University). Ostracode valves are abundant in the marlstones of the Zhada Basin and the ostracode faunal composition is highly variable with a predominance of limnocytherid species ( Fig. 7 ), which are endemic on the Tibetan Plateau. The assemblages are largely comparable to those of modern Tibetan lakes (e.g. Lake Nam Co, near Lhasa, ca. 1200 km east of Zhada; Wrozyna et al., accepted ) and hence allow the reconstruction of ancient paleo-lake environments. The lithofacies association of Unit 1 contains no ostracodes due to very coarse material and probably fluvial conditions, which are not favorable for ostracodes. Unit 2 is characterized by Leucocytherella sinensis and Candona xizangensis which are common in Lake Nam Co at all water depths, but show a trend to shallower water. However, rather than being indicative of water depth, their presence may be controlled preferably by a high tolerance towards unfavorable or fluctuating environmental conditions. This could be caused by the presence of fluctuating contents of coarse to fine sand in the deltaic environments. Significant for paleo-lake environmental reconstruction is, for example, the species ? Leucocythere dorsotuberosa f. postilirata that occurs at present below the thermocline (25–30 m) in Lake Nam Co ( Wrozyna, 2006; Wrozyna et al., accepted ). In the Zhada Basin this species is prominent in the middle portion of the section (Units 3 and 4) indicating deep-water conditions of a lacustrine environment. The alluvial fan facies (Unit 5) includes Leucocytherella sinensis and Ilyocyppris cf. mongolica that prefer more shallow water (<10 m). Species of Ilyocypris are often attributed to fluvial environments ( Delorme, 1969 ) and have generally thick-shelled valves robust for transport by water or even by wind ( Mischke et al., 2002 ). Limnocythere inopinata, which occurs in some horizons in Unit 5, is also a shallow-water indicator and is known for high salinity tolerance ( DeDeckker, 1981; Mischke et al., 2007 ); this suggests a decreasing lake level with slightly higher salinity. Other species, which are not yet classified, have no affinity to Lake Nam Co and seem to be endemic to the Zhada Basin region («unspecified ostracodes» of Fig. 7 ). In general, diversity of ostracode species is higher in the Zhada Basin than in Lake Nam Co. This hints in general at shallower water levels in the Zhada Basin. Shallow-water depths facilitate better food supply due to a higher growth potential of macrophytes and other water plants forming a preferable habitat of ostracodes. This leads to a higher ostracode diversity, which indicates a stable living environment. However, due to the high diversity and comparably little knowledge about Tibetan ostracodes, detailed paleoecologic interpretations are yet not possible. 5 Discussion 5.1 Environmental (facies) changes From a sequence-stratigraphic point of view ( Bohacs et al., 2000 ), the fluvio-lacustrine Zhada Basin can be best considered as overfilled lake basin because both sediment supply and potential accomodation are high. The middle part of the Zhada section represents a balance-filled lake basin because of the abundant and thick lake-floor turbidites and abundant carbonates (marlstones). The change from a bedload-dominated fluvial environment of Unit 1 to a nearshore deltaic environment of Unit 2 at ca. 90 m possibly coincides with strongly increasing discharge and rapid sedimentation within the fluvial system. This environmental change formed in response to rapid lake level rise and occurred somewhat after 7–9 Ma, as indicated by magnetostratigraphy ( Wang et al., 2008a ). In Unit 2 (90–220 m), maximum grain size occurs typically near the top of the sequence; during delta-lobe abandonment, rapid flooding terminates the depositional succession. However, despite the presence of well-developed depositional, coarsening-upwards cycles, no typical Gilbert-type, large-scale delta foreset beds have been observed throughout the Zhada section. This may be explained by strong, wind-induced current activity, which has the potential to destroy or mask large-scale sedimentary structures ( Blair and McPherson 2008 ). Alternatively, the strong retrogradational nature of the deltaic sequence did not allow the construction of large-scale foreset beds; instead, the supplied sediment was distributed in the repeatedly flooded, shallow coastal areas ( Einsele, 2000 ). Thus, sediment supply was largely outpaced by basin subsidence. Ostracode specimens found in this unit are especially tolerant of unfavorable or fluctuating shallow-water environmental conditions. Deeper lacustrine environments (Unit 3, 220–500 m) are indicated by abundant marlstones and intensely wave-rippled and hummocky cross-stratified sands, and are further constrained by abundant deep-water ostracodes (? Leucocythere dorsotuberosa f. postilirata; Wrozyna, 2006; Wrozyna et al., accepted ). During deposition of the overlying deltaic sands and marlstones (Unit 4, 500–600 m), the former lake became progressively filled by coarse clastic sediments from the southern basin margin; the depositional pattern is now progradational. Abundant mass flow deposits indicate a steeper slope gradient and probably higher sedimentation rates at that time. The abundance of coarse gravels increases at the expense of lacustrine marlstones upsection. In the uppermost portion of the section (Unit 5, 600–810 m), termination of the lake environment is indicated by an increasing number of thick massive, subaerially deposited, sheetflood-type gravel units. It is also interesting to note that ostracodes point towards higher salinity in the lake water suggesting a drier climate. After the accommodation space (i.e. the lake basin) had been filled with coarse clastics, an alluvial plain formed and sediment supply was probably strongly reduced. Alternatively, sedimentation may have persisted but the valley was no longer blocked; this scenario would have resulted in very rapid incision of the modern Sutlej River into the Zhada Basin deposits. 5.2 Possible tectonic and climatic implications Tectonic processes probably exerted an important control on lake basin development, especially the initiation of basin deposition. Basin subsidence persisted for at least 5 Myr and created accommodation space for more than 800 m sediment. The basin either must have been hydrologically closed, or blocked in a way such that the outflowing river was never able to deeply incise into the bedrock of the outflow region. Based on 3D stratigraphic forward modeling of foreland basin sequences, Clevis et al. (2004) could show that the onset of tectonic activity is indicated by rapid retrogradation of depositional systems and by widespread flooding. This depositional evolution is very similar to our observations from the Zhada Basin suggesting a significant tectonic contribution to the basin formation. The tectonic framework of the Zhada Basin is currently under discussion; Wang et al. (2008b) favor a half-graben structure, while the laterally persistent horizontal bedding is more consistent with either a full graben structure or a supradetachment basin, as suggested for the strata of the Pulan Basin (dip ca. 5°; Murphy et al., 2002 ), southeast of the Zhada Basin. However, since we have no evidence from the basin margin, the discussion on the tectonic regime is speculative at this point. An important influence of climatic changes on Zhada Basin deposition is suggested by the strong and probably rapid increase in discharge at ~ 70 m in the studied section, indicated by upward coarsening in the uppermost part of the fluvial Unit 1 (0–90 m), and leading to the subsequent depositional change from fluvial to lacustrine environments. This sedimentologic change goes also along with a pronounced petrologic change from highly abundant unstable heavy minerals (Unit 1) to a predominantly ultra-stable suite (Unit 2) suggesting significant changes in the weathering conditions and drainage patterns. We speculate that although tectonic subsidence is probably a first-order control on basin formation ( Clevis et al., 2004 ), this major sedimentologic change is due to a strong increase in precipitation and, presumably, regional monsoon intensification. Moreover, widespread wave-induced sedimentary structures like wave ripples and hummocky cross-stratification in Unit 2 point towards intense winds entering the Zhada basin at that time. If we apply the so far existing chronostratigraphic time frame of the Zhada Basin ( Qian, 1999; Wang et al., 2008a; Saylor et al., 2009 ), the base of the Zhada Basin succession is assigned an age of ca. 7–9 Ma, close to the time where many previous studies have demonstrated regional monsoon intensification (e.g., Flynn and Jacobs, 1982; Barry et al., 1982, 1985; Quade et al., 1989; Kroon et al., 1991; Nigrini, 1991; Prell and Kutzbach, 1992 ). It seems from the sedimentary record that the fluvial plain drowned and a lake rapidly expanded within relatively short time, as indicated by often retrogradational deltaic depositional sequences of Unit 2 (90–220 m). At that time (shortly after 9–7 Ma; Wang et al., 2008a ), sediment supply was outpaced by lake level rise. Ostracode assemblages are here predominantly composed of shallow-water species that tolerate unfavorable and fluctuating environments, which supports the interpretation of a delta-plain to delta-front depositional environment. We further speculate that the rhythmic depositional style of the alternating thick marlstones and thin sands of Unit 3 (220–500 m) was controlled by short-term climate fluctuations between humid and arid periods that caused significant changes in lake level and depositional patterns. Other examples of short-term climate control include the Neogene Niger delta (forward modeling of sediment supply; van der Zwan, 2002 ) and the Heqing Basin, China, for the past 1 Ma ( Hu et al., 2005 ). This may be also illustrated by the presence of both deep-water and shallow-water ostracode species, and by the increasing and decreasing content of unstable heavy minerals throughout Unit 3. In the upper part of the section, sediment supply strongly increased. This is illustrated by the prograding delta lobes of Unit 4 (500–600 m), and by the prominent gravel beds characteristic of Unit 5 (600–810 m). Based on the available magnetostratigraphic age constraints from two of the three published paleomagnetic studies of the Zhada Basin ( Qian, 1999; Saylor et al., 2009 ), it seems that the appearance of the very thick and massive gravel beds at ~ 600 m temporally correlates to the onset of Northern Hemisphere glaciation and winter monsoon strengthening at ~ 2.6 Ma ( An et al., 2001; Qiang et al., 2001 ). Thus, the Zhada section reveals a strong depositional cyclicity, which is documented in hierarchical stacking patterns at different scales based on increasing and decreasing grain sizes and carbonate content (see Fig. 5 A for outcrop scale cyclicity). As discussed above, the small-scale (~ 1–10 meter-scale) cycles that are best documented in the coarsening-upwards successions of the prograding deltas reflect most probably autocyclic processes, such as channel abandonment and delta-lobe switching. Climate-controlled small-scale cycles appear to have formed especially in Unit 3. Larger-scale (tens to >100 m) cycles, on the other hand, most likely document climatic fluctuations caused by intensity variations of the Asian monsoon (e.g., An et al., 2001; Hu et al., 2005 ). In addition, they may have been controlled by tectonic pulses which influenced the drainage system of the Zhada Basin at various temporal scales. 6 Conclusions We have presented sedimentologic, petrologic and paleontologic data from the late Neogene (ca. 9–7 to 1 Ma) Zhada Basin of SW-Tibet. The investigated composite Zhada section is located in a basin-central to basin marginal position, ca. 800 m thick, and composed of varying degrees of gravels, sands, and marlstones with fluctuating detrital contents. [1] Detailed sedimentologic investigation of the deposits revealed a succession of five fluvial and lacustrine lithofacies associations (LA). These are, from base to top, a fluvial LA of a bedload-dominated, braided-type river system (Unit 1, 0–90 m), a nearshore lacustrine LA showing the transition from a terrestrial plain into a lake (Unit 2, 90–220 m), alternating turbiditic sands and marlstones of an offshore lacustrine LA (Unit 3, 220–500 m), progradational delta-lobe sequences of a nearshore lacustrine fan-delta system (unit 4, 500–600 m), and a lacustrine to alluvial fan-delta/alluvial fan LA with coarse gravel deposits (Unit 5, 600–810 m). [2] The deltaic sediments document small-scale (m to dm) pro- and retrogradational fanlobes of a deltaic system without pronounced relief. Abundant hummocky cross-stratification is thought to have been triggered by (intensified?) storms. Repeated carbonate–siliciclastic depositional cycles of the lacustrine depositional sequence are interpreted to have been caused by climatic fluctuations rather than tectonic pulses because grain-size trends often occur gradational over a few meters and do not appear or disappear abruptly. [3] The sedimentary succession records the beginning, development, and destruction of a lake system associated with a fluvial plain. We interpret the establishment of lacustrine deposition as probably caused by a combination of tectonic basin subsidence and intensified summer monsoon precipitation, whereas the appearance of thick and massive conglomerate beds in the upper part of the section may reflect the onset of Northern Hemisphere glaciation and winter monsoon strengthening. [4] Petrologic analyses of heavy mineral and clast data of sands and gravels resulted in the recognition of two different provenance areas in the south and north/east. This is further supported by paleocurrent measurements. However, the varying contents of stable and unstable heavy minerals also point towards fluctuations of weathering conditions, and may therefore be related to changes in the Asian monsoon intensity after ca. 8 Ma (e.g., An et al., 2001 ). [5] Ostracode faunal assemblages, very abundant in the Zhada Basin sediments, revealed strong affinity to assemblages of modern Tibetan lakes (e.g. Lake NamCo). Based on the observations of the recent Lake Nam Co, we estimated the thermocline in the former Zhada Lake at ca. 25–30 m water depth using the occurrence of species ? L. dorsotuberosa f . postilirata and Ilyocypris cf. mongolica. Shallow water depths facilitate better food supply due to a higher growth potential of macrophytes and other water plants forming a preferable habitat of ostracodes. This leads to a higher ostracode diversity, which indicates a stable living environment. However, water depth is not the only factor determining the occurrence and distribution of ostracode species; too little is known on demands and tolerances of ostracode species against single environmental factors so far. z2UCQNWu.title: Knoevenagel condensation catalyzed by novel Nmm-based ionic liquids in water
z2UCQNWu.abstract: A series of novel N-methyl morpholine (Nmm) based ionic liquids with 1,2-propanediol group were synthesized and used as catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation at room temperature in water. Under the effect of the catalyst, various aldehydes or aliphatic ketones could react with a wide range of activated methylene compounds well, including malononitrile, alkyl cyanoacetate, cyanoacetamide, β-diketone, barbituric acid, 2-arylacetonitrile and thiazolidinedione. Furthermore, most of the products could be separated just by filtrating and washing with water. Additionally, the catalyst is recyclable and applicable for the large-scale synthesis.

kJzekpRH.title: Pollen and fossil wood's linkage with Mi-1 Glaciation in northeastern Tibetan Plateau, China
kJzekpRH.abstract: A more complete picture of the Cenozoic climate change and its driving mechanisms can only be obtained by an integrated analysis of widely distributed paleoclimate records from both oceanic and terrestrial sediments. However, there are fewer Cenozoic continental paleoclimatic records available when compared with the numerous marine records. Here, we present palynological results from the Xining Basin, northeastern Tibet, covering the Mi-1 Glaciation at around 23. Ma. We found that cold-tolerant conifers (such as Picea, Abies, Tsuga, and Larix) thrived while thermophilic plants (Rutaceae, Anacarabiaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Sapindaceae, Myrtaceae, and Podocarpaceae) declined in the Xining Basin during the Mi-1 Glaciation. Both before and after the Mi-1 Glaciation, there were few cold-tolerant conifers but more abundant thermophilic plants in the Xining Basin. Our results clearly show that climate in the northern and southern hemispheres was strongly coupled during the Mi-1 Glaciation and that cooling around 23. Ma was not limited to the southern hemisphere. We argue that the most plausible linking mechanism between Antarctic cooling and Asian cooling was the combination of low orbital eccentricity with a protracted node in obliquity. © 2013.

nQWnKc5b.title: Pliocene-Pleistocene climate change at the NE Tibetan Plateau deduced from lithofacies variation in the drill core SG-1, western Qaidam Basin, China
nQWnKc5b.abstract: The Pliocene-Pleistocene sedimentologic evolution of the western Qaidam Basin at the NE Tibetan Plateau was studied on the nearly thousand-meter-deep drill core SG-1 (spanning ca. 2.8-0.1 Ma), recovered from the Chahansilatu subdepression with an average recovery rate of 95%. Lithofacies variation records the regional climatic change in relation to Asian drying and Tibetan Plateau uplift. Sedimentary textures and structures demonstrate a continuous slight coarsening and an increase of evaporites upward. We recognized five lithofacies: (1) gray-black laminated mudstone, (2) gray massive mudstone and siltstone, (3) bedded halite, (4) loose muddy halite, and (5) brownish-yellowish saliferous siltstone and mudstone, representing (1) semi-deep fresh to semi-brackish lake, (2) shallow brackish lake, (3) perennial saline lake, (4) playa saline lake, and (5) saline mudflat conditions, respectively. Variation of the lithofacies through the core demonstrates a clear trend of lake shrinkage since the late Pliocene and the final termination of the Chahansilatu paleolake. Accelerations of lake shrinkages are observed at ca. 2.5 Ma, 2.2 Ma, 1.6 Ma, 1.2 Ma, 0.9 Ma, 0.6 Ma, and 0.1 Ma. Our results suggest that the long-term stepwise drying of the Asian inland may have been forced by the change of the global ice volume. Copyright © 2012, SEPM (Society for Sedimentary Geology).

F8kzu7Mm.title: Synthesis and Properties of Diglycidyl Ether of Tetrabromobisphenol-A
F8kzu7Mm.abstract: The parameters of the polymerization reaction(such as reaction temperature,reaction time,addition way of the alkali,the amount of the alkali used) were investigated to optimize the good synthesis procedure of tetrabromobiphenol-A type diglycidly ether(DGEBA).The optimal synthesis routes of DGEBA was described as follows: the addition of alkali was performed by two steps,the catalysis amount alkali was used in first step,etherification proceeded at 70℃ over a period of 0.5 h at first,then enhanced the temperature to 100～105 ℃ and continued etherifying for an additional 1.5 h;in the second step,the amount of alkali equivalent to that of TBBPA was charged,the mixture maintained at 100～105 ℃ over a 3h period.The product's characteristics was provided through Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy,proton nuclear magnetic resonance and thermal gravimetric analysis.The product with high purity(containing no TBBPA)exhibited good stability,its thermal decomposition temperature is over 300 ℃.

Csy4GykX.title: Loess recorded climatic change during the last glaciation on the eastern Tibetan Plateau, western Sichuan
Csy4GykX.abstract: The western Sichuan Plateau is located on the transitional zone of plateau climate and monsoon climate. Climatic characteristics of this region are very important for understanding of the Tibetan Plateau impacting on the surrounding climate.14C dating, stratigraphic correlation and grain size vs. age model were used to calculate ages for all sampling stratigraphic levels. Multi-proxy including grain size, color, magnetic susceptibility, and carbonate content analysis of Zhangla loess section at western Sichuan Plateau revealed a detailed history of climate changes since 104 ka B.P. The long-term trend of increasing grain size, middle grain sizes are 17.6 and 17.7 μm in MIS (marine isotope stage) 3 and 4, may be explained in part by a rapid uplift of the Tibetan Plateau events. The climate showed sub-orbital scale fluctuations similarity to millennial-scale climatic changes recorded in Nanjing stalagmite. The strength of H(heinrich) 2 significantly higher than H1. It may indicate that the climate system at high latitudes in the Northern Hemisphere had played an important role. There were two distinct weakening aridification recorded in MIS3, during 28-31 ka and 42-45 ka. They may suggest that the climate system also controlled by factors at low latitudes.

zB48Hb3g.title: Evidence for early (≥12.7 Ma) eolian dust impact on river chemistry in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau
zB48Hb3g.abstract: Abstract   As one of the largest dust sources on the Earthu0027s surface, dryland in Central Asia gives rise to thick eolian deposits over East Asia (e.g., the Chinese Loess Plateau, CLP) and significantly influences the regional hydrochemistry in the downwind drainage areas. However, the formation of thick eolian dust deposits requires not only climatic prerequisites for dust emission and transport but also climatic and topographic conditions favourable for deposition and accumulation. The scarcity of widespread eolian deposition around the CLP before 7-8 Ma hinders a full understanding of the processes and mechanisms of Central Asian aridification. The deposition of eolian dust also impacts the hydrogeochemistry of fluvial systems and the precipitation of authigenic phases in continental sedimentary systems could be an archive for studying eolian dust dynamics when pure eolian deposits are scarce. Here, we present the Ca-Mg-Sr concentrations and  87 Sr/ 86 Sr isotope compositions of bulk carbonates in a new fluvial sequence (12.7-4.8 Ma) of the Xining Basin. The Mg/Ca and Sr/Ca ratios of the carbonate describe a power law relationship with a power coefficient of ∼0.8, lower than the coefficient characteristic of prior calcite precipitation (PCP). An input of eolian dust with the dissolution of Mg-rich carbonate is likely responsible for the deviation from a pure PCP process. The bulk carbonates also show a general decrease of  87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios from 12.7 to 4.8 Ma, with a transition around 8.6 Ma revealed by lower Sr/Mg ratios. The comparison of these proxies to a previously reported fluvial section (12.2-5.1 Ma) in the Linxia Basin, ∼200 km to the southeast, shows that the  87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios of the bulk carbonates and water-soluble salts in the Linxia Basin are around 0.7098, which is 0.0018 lower than those in the Xining Basin before 8.6 Ma, but shows a significant rise between 8.6 and 7.0 Ma. The two basins share the same range of carbonate  87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios when sediments are younger than 7 Ma. For the last 7 Myrs, the evolution of the  87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios in bulk carbonates of fluvial sediments and Pliocene-Quaternary eolian deposits found in the Xining Basin are similar to those in typical eolian red clays/loess-palaeosol sequences on the CLP. These results suggest a transition of the hydrochemical regime at 8.6 Ma in the Linxia Basin from a catchment only influenced by the weathering of its bedrock to one significantly impacted by eolian dust input. In the Xining Basin, the carbonate elemental and  87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios are consistent with a hydrochemistry more impacted by the presence of the eolian dust. There, the dust input occurred earlier, at ≥12.7 Ma, though it has strengthened since 8.6 Ma. The eolian dust impact on fluvial systems in the Xining Basin was much earlier than in the Linxia Basin and also preceded the initial accumulation of widespread eolian red clays on the CLP (7-8 Ma), suggesting a temporally propagating and spatially stepwise expansion of eolian dust delivery across the Asian inland during the late Cenozoic.

ysYexuCh.title: Copper-catalyzed one-pot synthesis of 1,2,4-triazoles from nitriles and hydroxylamine.
ysYexuCh.abstract: A simple and efficient copper-catalyzed one-pot synthesis of substituted 1,2,4-triazoles through reactions of two nitriles with hydroxylamine has been developed. The protocol uses simple and readily available nitriles and hydroxylamine hydrochloride as the starting materials and inexpensive Cu(OAc)2 as the catalyst, and the corresponding 1,2,4-triazole derivatives are obtained in moderate to good yields. The reactions include sequential intermolecular addition of hydroxylamine to one nitrile to provide amidoxime, copper-catalyzed treatment of the amidoxime with another nitrile, and intramolecular dehydration/cyclization. This finding provides a new and useful strategy for synthesis of 1,2,4-triazole derivatives.

uNZ0lyzc.title: Regularity analysis of deacetylase SIRT1 expression in different pig organs and tissues
uNZ0lyzc.abstract: Objective The present experiment was aimed to analyze the regularity of deacetylase SIRT1 expression in the different pig tissues in order to provide a foundation for the study of SIRT1 gene function.Method By using the RTPCR and Western blotting methods,the SIRT1 mRNA and protein expression levels in various pig tissues,including brain,liver,pancreas,ovary,kidney,fat,heart,spleen,etc.,were analyzed.Result By testing all the various pig organs and tissues,the SIRT1 mRNA and protein expression were discovered in all tested tissues,and the highest expression was found in the ovary and the brain,while the lowest expression was found in the heart.Conclusion The regular expressions of deacetylase SIRT1 in the different tissues of pig were discovered.The research results suggested that the SIRT1 gene was closely related to the pig fat metabolism and reproduction activities,and the SIRT1 gene could directly or indirectly regulate energy metabolism and reproduction activities.

zil1jLKv.title: An astronomically tuned 8.1 Ma eolian record from the Chinese Loess Plateau and its implication on the evolution of Asian monsoon
zil1jLKv.abstract: The Chinese loess-paleosol sequences have led to a great understanding of the evolution of the East Asian monsoon (EAM) in the Quaternary. However, evolution of the EAM in the late Miocene and Pliocene is quite blurry, hindering our understanding of the mechanisms driving the EAM. Thus, we obtained high-resolution grain size records of 8.1 Ma from the thickest eolian Red Clay sequence at Chaona on the Chinese central Loess Plateau, and astronomically tuned the grain size records to the orbital variation with a time resolution of 1.5 ka to 5.8 ka. The variability of coarse size fraction, a recognized proxy for the East Asian winter monsoon (EAWM), indicates a persistent but stepwise intensification of the EAWM at ca. 5.5 Ma, 3.6 Ma, 2.6 Ma and 1 Ma. Filtering of this proxy record at 100, 41, and 21 ka bands was conducted to trace the evolution of the EAWM in a frequency domain over 8.1 Ma. Temporal variations of these three cycles show a remarkable simultaneous enhancement at ca. 5.5 Ma, indicating a synchronous intensification of high and low latitude signals in the EAWM record. We suggest that the closure of Panama Seaway to form the North Atlantic thermohaline circulation and the high latitude cooling during this time might collectively trigger such a response. Copyright 2011 by the American Geophysical Union.

GzQPEfE5.title: Supramolecular interactions via hydrogen bonding contributing to citric-acid derived carbon dots with high quantum yield and sensitive photoluminescence
GzQPEfE5.abstract: Herein, we report the characterization of highly fluorescent citric-acid derived carbon dots (CACDs) synthesized by hydrothermal treatment of citric acid and diethylenetriamine below 200 °C. After being purified using a gel permeation chromatography cleanup system, the complexity and chemical composition of the CACDs were evaluated by liquid chromatography coupled with high-resolution Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry. The fluorophores consisted of five-membered ring fused 2-pyridones identified as the photoluminescence origin. M06-2X density functional calculations, surface tension and morphological studies suggested DETA@5CA serves as the main building block to fabricate supramolecular aggregates. Then we proposed that the dimeric and trimeric fluorophores coupled with DETA@5CA led to “dot” topologies in the CACDs solution under the effect of hydrogen bonding. In aqueous solution, the CACDs exhibited narrowly dispersed optical properties and a high fluorescent quantum yield (∼98%). Moreover, the supramolecular interaction induced CACDs have high sensitivity under various ambient conditions, such as pH, organic solvents and metal ions.
