shWbPMMy.title: Application value of six major genes for molecular breeding of Suzhong swine
shWbPMMy.abstract: The polymorphisms of Hal,RN,ESR,FSHβ,IGF-1 and MC4R genes were detected by PCR-RFLP in Suzhong swine(n=180),Erhualian swine(n=64),Meishan swine(n=60),Landrace swine(n=46),Large white swine(n=48),and Pietrain swine(n=35),and the application value of these genes for molecular breeding in Suzhong swine population was assessed.Polymorphisms were identified for six major genes among the swine breeds.In Suzhong swine population,NN and Nn genotypes of Hal gene,RN-/rn+ and rn+/rn+ genotypes of RN gene were found.Predominant genotypes of ESR,FSHβ,IGF-1 and MC4R genes were observed in the Suzhong swine mentioned above.The results indicate these major genes are useful for molecular breeding of Suzhong swine.

MXZbpO4u.title: The combination of docetaxel and cisplatin and fluorouraacil as neoadjuvant chemotherapy in the treatment of advanced gastric cancer
MXZbpO4u.abstract: Objective To evaluate the efficacy and toxicity of docetaxel(TAX),cisplatin (CDDP) plus fluorouracil(5-FU)/CF as the neoadjuvant chemotherapy (DCF) in the treatment of locally advanced gastric cancer(LAGC).Methods From October 2003 to October 2004,18 patients with LAGC were treated with DCF chemotherapy before operation,neoadjuvant chemotherapy regimens containing docetaxel(D),75mg/m2(days 1), cisplatin(C),30mg/m2 (days,1 to 3) plus fluorouracil (F),500mg/m2 (days,1 to 5),CF 100mg IV(days,1 to 5)were administered every 3 weeks for three cycles before local treatment.The response in the primary tumor and the chemotherapy toxicity were observed in each patient.Results Theresponse in the primary tumor?押 clinical efficacy rate was 55.6%(10/18,16.7% CR and 38.9% PR,27.8% SD and 16.7% PD).Pathological response rate was 11.1%, pathological complete response was found in 2 cases.The most common toxicities were leukocytopenia,nausea/vomiting and alopcia.Leucopenia of grade 3-4 was reported in 4 cases of the patients(22.2%),but there was no chemotherapy related toxic severy contract and death.Conclusion The combination of docetaxel,cisplatin plus fluorouracil is a very effective and well-tolerated regimen as neoadjuvant chemotherapy for the LAGC.
keywords: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy Locally advanced gastric cancer Docetaxel Cisplatin Fluorouracil/CF

ZlsZMbaU.title: The vegetation and climate change during Neocene and Early Quaternary in Jiuxi Basin, China
ZlsZMbaU.abstract:
Sporopollen record in the Laojunmiao Section at Yumen in the Hexi Corridor foreland depression at the northern margin of the
 Tibetan Plateau revealed that during the period of 13.0–11.15 Ma the ecological environment of the Jiuxi Basin is characterized
 by steppe vegetation and a semi-moist climate. During 11.16–8.60 Ma prevailed forests of cypress and a still warmer, moister
 climate; steppe vegetation and dry climate began probably at about 8.6 Ma. Although aridification had been relaxed time and
 again during 8.40–6.93 Ma (forest-steppe, warm-semi-moist), 6.64–5.67 Ma (open-forest and steppe, warmer-semi-moist) and 5.42–4.96
 Ma (steppe, semi-arid), the climate in the region became drier and drier in response to the fre-quent occurrence of aridity
 during 6.93–6.64 Ma (steppe, semi-arid), 5.67–5.42 Ma (de-sert-steppe, arid), 3.66–3.30 Ma (desert-steppe, arid) and 2.56–2.21
 Ma (desert, arid). Perhaps the important findings of our study are the notable expansion of drought-enduring plants during
 3.66–3.30 Ma and about 2.56 Ma and the replacement of vegetation by vast arid desert.

vbDp9sj0.title: Pliocene synchronous rapid uplift of the Tibet Plateau: A summary of K-Ar and paleomagnetic dating of the Main Tibet surface river terraces and basin sediments
vbDp9sj0.abstract: Timing of the uplift of the Tibet Plateau provides very important boundaries to understand the mechanism of mountain building during continental collision and tectonism-climate coupling. Evidences from geology, geophysics, geomorphology and geography have resulted in various models of the uplift of the Plateau, some of which are contradictory. Precise data from the eastern and northern margins of the Plateau, critical to the reconstruction and full-view of the uplift, has been very sparse in the past. To fill this gap the Chinese Government launched three successive National Tibetan Projects (1993-1996; 1997-2000; 1998-2002; total at 9 million US$) in order to collect quantitative data on Plateau collision and uplift processes and their impacts on environment and ecology. Here we make a short summarization of the results, largely done in 2000, from dating of the Tibet surface and the Plateau marginal river terraces and basin sediments, which are sensitive to pure surface uplift, a key to judge a geomorphological rather than geological uplift of the Tibet Plateau. Along the entire foredeep bordered by the North Marginal Thrust (Kunlun-Altun-Qilian-Longmeng Trusts) to the north and east, a thick package of Cenozoic sediments records the whole history of the Plateau uplift process. It can be lithologically divided into three large units from top to bottom: light colored sediments, boulder conglomerates and red beds. The red beds are either fine sediments of lacustrine and delta origins or relatively coarser sediments of braided river and/or fan delta origin. The boulder conglomerate, mostly unconformably superimposed on the red beds, has long been viewed as evidence of rapid uplift of the Tibet Plateau. The light colored sediments are mostly eolian (desert-gobi and loess) and/or fluviolacustrine deposits. These sequences hold the key to the history of Plateau uplift. Control sections from Chaona in the Pingliang-Lingtai Basin (107.2°E, 35.1°N, eastern margin of Liupan Shan Mountains - a tectonic boundary of the NE Tibet Plateau), Linxia (103.2°E, 35.6°N) and Guide Basins (101.5°E, 36°N, NE Tibet Plateau) and Jiuquan Basin (97.5°E, 39.8°N, N Tibet Plateau) were chosen for detailed stratigraphic analysis in this study. Detailed paleomagnetic, paleontological, fission track, ESR and TL dating of these stratigraphic sequences reveal that during the Cenozoic, an initial uplift of the northern Tibetan Plateau in response to early strong collision of India with Asia occurred at ∼36-30 Ma BP, which formed the basins and coarse sediments (fine conglomerate) at basin bottom. Up-fining sediments (mostly siltstone and mudstone) until ∼24 Ma suggest that the uplifted surface was reduced to a lowland or so-called peneplain or planation surface. A very strong tectonic compression, accompanied with a certain extent uplift of the northern Tibet Plateau which broke up the early planation surface, happened at ∼24-22 Ma, as indicated by strong folding of Oligocene sediments and widely distributed unconformity between the Oligocene and Miocene boundary. The early Miocene river gravel and fan delta sandstone and the middle Miocene lacustrine siltstone and mudstone indicate that the moderately raised Tibet landform was eroded down again to a lowland, i.e. the present-uplifted Main Tibet surface. Until ∼8 Ma BP, the northern Tibet Plateau began to relatively strong but progressive uplift, as indicated by a progressive unconformity and a gradual change in facies from lacustrine-dominated environment via fan delta (sandstone) to alluvial fan (conglomerates) in conjunction with the initial disintegration of the Main surface. At ∼3.6 Ma BP rapid uplift occurs, characterized by the synchronism of faulting and folding of red beds and the subsequent appearance of boulder conglomerates. Episodic volcanic rocks covering the Main surface provide a parallel approach to date the Plateau planation surface. Previous K-Ar and Ar-Ar dating of those volcanic rocks yield ages ranging from 24 to 7 Ma BP. We obtained a youngest K-Ar age of the volcanic rocks at ∼3.5 Ma BP from the eastern Tibet Plateau surface. Since these rocks and the Main surface were incised deeply by rivers, the rocks suggest that the Main surface was broken down and uplifted at ∼3.5 Ma BP, in good agreement with our basin sediment records above. Successive stepwise rapid uplifts occurred at ∼2.6, 1.8-1.7, 1.2, 0.9-0.8, and 0.15 Ma BP, manifested in the folding of conglomerates and large scale incision of the land surface by rivers. Finally we should stress that our evidence show a nearly synchronous, rather than progradated, uplift of the eastern and northern Tibet Plateau initiated at ∼8 Ma BP and began rapid since ∼3.6 Ma BP, which finally lead to a present, rather than 14 Ma BP or 8 Ma BP, maximum raised Plateau.

cJnBoyns.title: Extended drought in the interior of Central Asia since the Pliocene reconstructed from sporopollen records
cJnBoyns.abstract: A sporopollen record recovered from 5.3–1.83 Ma sediments was obtained from the lacustrine Yahu section in the central Qaidam Basin of inner Asia. The results provide evidence for vertical zonation of vegetation on the mountains surrounding the basin during the Pliocene and development of forests on the mountains and grasslands around the lake basin. At 3.6 Ma, herbaceous plants (especially xerophytic plants such as Artemisia , Chenopodiaceae and Ephedra ) increased for a short time within the basin. Xerophytic plants increased continually after 2.6 Ma in the basin, which exhibited steppe vegetation, and the climate became drier than before. These vegetation changes in the region of the Yahu section suggest a process of stepwise aridification in Central Asia's interior since the Pliocene, and it may be related to global cooling and uplift of the Tibetan Plateau. Keywords Plio-Pleistocene Qaidam Basin sporopollen record aridification 1 Introduction Arid and semi-arid environments cover more than 40% of the global land surface. As the largest temperate arid region, Central Asia has attracted wide interests for its aridification. The drying appears to correspond closely with the uplift of the Tibetan Plateau, the retreat of the Northern Tethys, the growth of Arctic ice, and the evolution of the East Asian monsoon ( Ruddiman and Kutzbach, 1989; Li, 1995; Ramstein et al., 1997; Rea et al., 1998; Ding and Sun, 1998; Li and Fang, 1999; An et al., 2001, 2006; Guo et al., 2002 ). Various researchers have shown that the aridification of the modern landscape began during the Miocene (or even earlier), intensified during the late Miocene, and finally reached today's conditions during the Quaternary ( Teilhard, 1937; Li et al., 1979; Zhou, 1982; Zhang, 1981; Liu and Ding, 1983; Wang, 1990; Ding and Sun, 1998; An et al. 2001, 2006; Guo et al., 2002 ). However, most of the existing evidence on this issue has been obtained indirectly, largely from the aeolian records from the Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP) (e.g., An et al., 2001, 2006; Guo et al., 2002; Liu and Ding, 1983; Ding and Sun, 1998, 1999; Sun et al., 2008; Wu et al., 2007 ), and little from inland arid areas ( Fang et al., 2002a, 2002b; Zheng et al., 2000, 2002; Sun and Liu, 2006 ). A shortage exists of stable and continuous sediment records to provide convincing evidence. At the Qaidam Basin (an inland arid area of China, see Fig. 1 ), continuous and well-exposed Cenozoic lacustrine sediments have been deposited. Sporopollen records obtained from lacustrine sediments provide ideal organic proxies for studying changes in the regional climate and environment. This study therefore uses the sporopollen record of those Qaidam Basin lacustrine sediments to reconstruct its vegetation history, which provides a unique opportunity to study the process of aridification in Northwest China even Central Asia. 2 Geography and geology The Qaidam Basin ( Fig. 1 ), on the northeastern edge of the Tibetan Plateau, lies between 36°–39°N Latitude and 90°–98°E Longitude. The Altun, Qilian, and Kunlun mountains surround this intermontane basin. The Basin lies at an elevation of 2600 to 3200 m, keeping its continental climate cold (mean annual temperature 0–5 °C) and windy. Moreover, an annual precipitation decrease from 100–200 mm at the southeast to 50 mm at the central even to 20 mm at the northwest of the basin, but a potential annual evaporation is over 20 times greater than precipitation, so the climate of the basin remains very dry. Most of the Qaidam Basin supports sparse desert vegetation on gravelly, well-drained soils. Flat areas farther from the mountains may almost completely lack vegetation. The eastern part of the basin has a relatively higher level of vegetation coverage. Dominant species include the cold-tolerant, xerophytic shrub, haloxylon ammodendron, the tamarisk , and the gymnosperm Ephedra przewalski . Other species include Nitraria vannoides , Salsola collina , and Tamarix spp . The western part of the basin consists of arid desert with almost no vegetation at all, including expanses of gravel, shifting sand and some salt deposits. Extensive saline meadows and salt marshes occur in the southern part of the basin. Characteristic vegetation in this frigid, flooded, saline/alkaline environment consists of Koresia littledalei , Aneurolepidium dasistachyum , and Polygonum sibiricum . Surrounding mountain slopes at higher elevations support shrubs adapted to cold, windy, semi-arid conditions. This alpine desert vegetation consists mainly of Ajania tibetica and the cushion plant Ceratoides compacta . Small needle-grasses like Stipa subsessiliflora form a thin ground cover in such places ( Wu, 1995 ). The selected section lies on the northeast limb of the Yahu anticline, at an elevation of 2863–2741 m, central of the Qaidam Basin ( Fig. 1 ). The field strata include the Pliocene Shizigou Formation and the Pleistocene Qigequan Formation ( Fig. 2 ). The former has an exposure of 430 m, characterized by brown and green sandstones and shale sands. The latter consists of 248 m of thickness, and consists mainly of brown and gray mudstone, gypsum sandstone, including some marlite and oolitic sandstone. Zhang et al. (submitted) assigned a stratigraphic age for the Yahu section to a range between 5.3 and 1.83 Ma with a stratigraphic lacuna of about 0.5 Ma from 4.2 to 3.7 Ma, based on paleomagnetism and fossils of ostracods and fish ( Fig. 2 ). A total of 13 normal and 13 reversed polarity intervals have been recorded in the Yahu section, marked as N1–N13 and R1–R13 in Fig. 2 , respectively. Candona yanhuensis and Eucypris inflate only appeared at ~ 2.0 Ma ( Yang, 1981 ), the upper age of the layers where they were found was controlled. Therefore, the observed polarities fit very well within chrons C2n–C3n of the Geomagnetic Polarity Time Scale of Cande and Kent (1995) . Thus the whole section was estimated to have been deposited between 1.83 and 5.3 Ma. But because of a small twist at the anticline a few strata are missing ( Fig. 2 ). 3 Materials and methods Our study collected 300 samples for palynological analysis of the Yahu section, at intervals of 1–3 m. Sediment samples ranging from 15 to 150 g were processed following a standard method ( Cour, 1974 ): acid digestion (treated with HCl and HF acid, removing carbonates and silicates respectively), concentration of the palynomorphs (sieved through a 10 μm mesh to remove the fine fraction) ( Ma et al., 1998 ). Finally the prepared specimens were mounted in glycerol for identification. All samples have been studied at the Lanzhou University and the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, the Chinese Academy of Sciences by comparing with officially published pollen plates and modern pollen slides preserved in the Geography Department of Lanzhou University. Some of the samples were double checked at the Tuebingen University, Germany. 4 Sporopollen record Between 100 and 646 pollen grains were counted from each of the 251 samples. The sporopollen results show that the samples at the bottom of the Yahu section contain abundant pollen grains. The content often reached more than 100 grains/g, so we identified at least 300 grains per sample under the microscope. Although the upper section contained fewer pollen grains, more than 100 grains were generally counted per sample (fewer than 10% of the samples contained less than 100 grains maybe because of preservation). The pollen taxa ( Table 1 ) have been assigned to 22 families and 45 genera. These include arboreal trees, some scrubby and herbaceous taxa, as well as a few pteridophyte and algal spores, but which all were excluded from the total pollen sum when we calculated pollen percentages. Most paleoclimate reconstructions rely on the ecological character of living taxa that sensitively reflect climate conditions. For example, the xerophilous plants Artemisia , Chenopodiaceae, Ephedra and Nitraria all reflect arid conditions. Therefore we use them as proxies for arid conditions, and define an Aridity Factor lnA: lnA = ln % A r t e m s i a + % Chenopodiaceae + % E p h e d r a + % N i t r a r i a / 1 − % A r t e m s i a + % Chenopodiaceae + % E p h e d r a + % N i t r a r i a . Greater lnA values indicate increasingly arid climates. This study interprets climate changes from lnA variations, the percentages of wet-resistant coniferous trees ( Picea + Abies , Pinus ), broadleaved trees, selected shrubs and herbs ( Ephedra , Artemisia , Chenopodiaceae), the relation of Arboral Pollen (AP) to Non Arboral Pollen (NAP) AP/NAP, and the concentrations of Pediastrum in the assemblages ( Fig. 3 ). The pollen diagram does not present other taxa, but they are named in the descriptions of the relevant pollen zones. The Pliocene–Pleistocene vegetation history of the Qaidam Basin naturally divides into three stages: 4.1 Stage I (0–140 m depth, 5.3–3.6 Ma) This stage shows the highest pollen concentrations, characterized by high values of AP (the average of AP/NAP is 9.6, varying from 0.1 to 38.6), attributed mainly to coniferous taxa (average of 70%), which are dominated by Picea and Abies (0.4% ~ 82.7%), Pinus (1.6% ~ 68.2%) and Cedrus (0 – 4.1%). Broadleaved trees (up to 7.7%) such as Betula , Quercus , Ulmus , Juglans , Salix, Alnus , Carya , Ruta , Melia are common. NAP taxa are dominated by Gramineae (up to 6.5%), and Compositae, Ephedra (0–8.2%, but almost 16% in one sample). The average of lnA in this stage is the lowest of the entire section (average −2, varying from −5.2 to 2.4). Additionally, a few fern spores have been found, consisting of Polypodiaceae, Selaginella , Lycopodium , and Pteris . Also remains of Pediastrum, a planctonic freshwater alga, are well preserved and rather abundant (average of ~ 65 grains/100 g). 4.2 Stage II (140–420 m depth, 3.6–2.6 Ma) A high proportion of AP still characterizes this stage (average AP/NAP of 6.7), accompanied by a decrease of Picea and Abies (2%–88.8%), Pinus (2.2%–65%), and slight increases of Ulmus (0–3.1%) and Betula (0–2.8%). Pollen grains of Cedrus , Tsuga , Podocarpus, Ruta , Melia , Ericaceae are seldom recorded. The percentages of shrubs and herbs exceed those in stage I, especially between 335 and 360 m (corresponding to ages from 2.94 to 2.85 Ma), where changes from 47.9% to 90% exist. The main difference between stage II and stage I is the relative increase in abundance of xerophytic plants (by an average of > 30%), such as Ephedra , Artemisia (0.3%–68%), and Chenopodiaceae (0.2%–51.5%), so that the lnA is higher (average −1.46, varying from −5.1 to 1.8). In addition, only a few samples contain Pediastrum spores, indicating lower concentrations than in stage I (average 15 grains/100 g). 4.3 Stage III (420–678 m depth，2.6–1.83 Ma) The pollen concentrations in the samples of this stage fluctuate greatly; only a few pollen grains have been detected in some samples. The average AP/NAP values (0.1–31) decrease considerably from 6.7 to 2.9. Coniferous trees like Picea and Abies (1.1%–39.8%) abruptly decrease except at a highstand (12.6%–79.6%) at the stratigraphic level between 600 and 635 m (corresponding to an age of 2.02–1.95 Ma). The herbaceous plants, however, show a drastic increase (up to 92.4%) consisting mainly of Ephedra (0–24%), Artemisia, and Chenopodiaceae. Betula (0–2.7%) and Ulmus (0–4%) contribute minor amounts, while the typical subtropical plants like Pterocarya , Melia disappear, and xerophytic plants reach their highest values (average 38%), these lead to the highest lnA values (average −0.7, varying from −3.7 to 1.7). The concentrations of Pediastrum still continued to decrease (average 2 grains/100 g), and no Pediastrum was found in most samples. 5 Discussion Modern surface pollen studies suggest that palynomorph assemblages generally over-represent Pinus , Artemisia and Chenopodiaceae (e.g., Wu and Sun, 1987; Li and Yao, 1990; Yan, 1991; Weng et al., 1993; Wang et al., 1996; Li, 1998 ). In this study, their high values may result from their high pollen production. On the other hand, the palynomorph results from the Yahu section provide evidence that the vertical vegetation zonation around the Qaidam Basin has existed since 5.3 Ma. However, our pollen findings indicate that taxa producing high amounts of pollen grains (such as Pinaceae living at high elevations surrounding the basin) also existed abundantly throughout this period. Broadleaved trees however, situated on lower slopes around the basin, produce low amounts of pollen and appear with low percentages in the pollen report. Finally, xerophytic plants (like Artemisia , Chenopodiaceae) show relatively higher percentages because of their habitat near the palaeo-lake. The reason for higher percentages of coniferous trees and lower broadleaved trees in this section, however, still requires further study. High percentages of coniferous trees, broadleaved trees and herbs (such as Gramineae and Compositae) characterize the pollen assemblages during the period of 5.3–3.6 Ma. This probably suggests a grassland zone within the basin vegetation. Conifers (such as Picea and Abies ) covered the high mountainous hinterland. The lower elevations have been dominated by a mixed mesophytic forest consisting of Pinus , Cedrus and temperate deciduous or subtropical trees, including Betula , Alnus , Acer , Ulmus , Juglans and Quercus, which represent a temperate to warm temperate climate. Pediastrum occurs frequently in freshwater environments, being part of the phytoplanktonic communities. Many studies have shown its contents can effectively indicate a lake's salinity or depth ( Sun and Wu, 1987; Xu et al., 2004; Sarmaja-Korjonen et al., 2006; Zhao et al., 2007 ), which relates to the degree of drought in the surrounding environment. Hence, the appearance of Pediastrum may indicate relatively wet conditions during this period. The first main ecologic environmental shift, indicated by higher values of the aridity factor lnA (increasing from −2 to −1.4) and lower AP/NAP ratios (averages decreasing from 9.6 to 6.7), occurred at about 3.6 Ma. The percentages of thermophilous subtropical trees (such as Ericaceae, Melia ) decreased and the xerophytic plants increased their fraction from 20.8% to 30.3%, indicating a widely spreading steppe in response to cooler and drier climatic conditions. A second environmental shift occurred at ~ 2.6 Ma, manifested by the disappearance of some subtropical trees and a dramatic expansion of drought-tolerant plants. The aridity factor lnA increased from −1.4 to −0.7, the value AP/NAP clearly dropped (averages falling from 6.7 to 2.9), Podocarpus and Tsuga nearly disappeared in the palynomorph report, and Pediastrum ceased appearance in most of samples. During the period of 2.6–1.83 Ma, Chenopodiaceae, Artemisia , Aster , Ephedra , Nitraria and Tamarix grew more widespread in the basin, indicating the expansion of the steppe and a drier climate. Lithologic changes within the section investigated provide evidence supporting the major conclusions of our palynological work. The bottom of the section contains many fossil fish and layers with plant debris; while the number and size of gypsum veins increase somewhat in the middle of the stratigraphic section. The upper portion of the section contains gypsum sandstones as well as gypsum and Glauber's salt (hydrated sodium sulfate) layers. Overall, this indicates a trend towards an increasingly dry climate. However, really thick gypsum and halite layers have never been found in the upper part of the section. Enhanced aridity since 3.6 Ma corresponds with other analyses in adjacent areas. For example, Ephedra -Chenopodiaceae pollen characterize the Pliocene sporopollen assemblage of the Kuche Formation, north of the Tarim Basin ( Cao et al., 2001 ), whereas Chenopodiaceae, Ephedra and Artemisia dominate in the southern part of the Tarim Basin ( Cao et al., 2001 ) ( Fig.1 ). Dry herbs replaced temperate broadleaved trees at ~ 3.6 Ma in the Jiuxi Basin ( Ma et al., 2005 ) ( Fig. 1 ). Moreover, these changes correlate with the sharp increase in aeolian flux in the Red Clay formation of the CLP (e.g., An et al., 2001, 2006; Guo et al., 2002; Ding and Sun, 1998, 1999; Sun et al., 2008; Zheng et al., 2004 ) and into the North Pacific ( Rea et al., 1998 ) around 3.6 Ma, and this can be confirmed by other records at the CLP, e.g., (1) considerable carbon isotopic data from fossil teeth and soil carbonates from the CLP suggest a humid climate during the late Miocene–early Pliocene ( Passey et al., 2009 ); (2) during the period 5.4–3.4 Ma, thermo-humidiphilous mollusk taxa found at Xifeng ( Fig. 1 ) show a warm and wet climate, whereas after 3.4 Ma their numbers decreased ( Wu et al., 2006; Li and Wu, 2010 ); and (3) biomarker records from the Chaona section ( Fig. 1 ) indicate that vegetation degraded from forest types at ~ 3.8 Ma ( Bai et al., 2009 ). At 2.6 Ma, the slightly brackish-water ostracoda Chinghaicypris Crassa replaced the pre-existing fresh and slightly brackish-water ostracoda taxa (e.g., Microlimnocythere sinensis ) in the Yahu area ( Yang, 1981 ), indicating a clear drying trend. This can be showed by other sporopollen records from adjacent areas, e.g. (1) vegetation evolved from a grassland to a desert steppe in the Jiuxi Basin ( Fig. 1 ) at 2.56 Ma ( Ma et al., 2005 ); (2) at 2.51 Ma, a broad-leaved forest-grassland changed to an open forest-steppe in the Weihe Basin ( Fig. 1 ) ( Tong et al., 2000 ), and (3) a Cupressaceae forest shifted to a steppe at Chaona ( Fig. 1 ) at 2.6 Ma ( Wu et al., 2007 ). Another dramatic change occurred in aeolian dust flux to the Pacific at ~ 2.6 Ma ( Shackleton et al., 1995 ), coincident with the onset of loess accumulation in north-central China. The above two shifts occurred at 3.6 Ma and 2.6 Ma indicated by the sporopollen record of the Yahu section was probably induced by the combined effects of the phased uplift of the Tibetan Plateau and the intensive onset of the Northern Hemisphere glaciation. They may considerably weaken the ocean evaporation and transportation of water vapor into Asian inland, thus enhancing the aridification of the Qaidam basin since that time. 6 Conclusion The sporopollen record from the Yahu section reveals stepwise aridification around the Qaidam Basin. It provides evidence for a vertical zonation of vegetation during the early Pliocene. Temperate forests grew mainly on the surrounding mountains, while grasslands (dominated by Compositae and Gramineae) covered most of the basin plains around the lake. After 3.6 Ma, xerophilous plants increased and thermophilous trees decreased, indicating a drier climate. Since 2.6 Ma, the average percentages of xerophilous plants have continued to increase, suggesting an ongoing expansion of the steppe. This stepwise drying of the Qaidam Basin was probably induced by the combined effects of the phased uplift of the Tibetan Plateau and the global cooling. Special thanks to Editor Thomas M. Cronin, Dr. Nie Junsheng and other anonymous reviewer for their valuable suggestions and comments on this paper and Prof. Bill Isherwood for help with English improvement. lyGu9sgc.title: The Discovery and Significance of the Fossil Woods in the Bottom of Chetougou Formation in Xiejia Section,Xining Basin
lyGu9sgc.abstract: The original burial fossil woods excavation at the bottom of the Chetougou Formation in Xiejia section,Xining Basin,is not only the first found of the big plant fossil in the arid-semiarid region in NW China,but also greatly significant to research the evolution of plant ecological environment and even the tectonic movement in northeastern Tibetan Plateau.Through the comprehensive analysis of the buried fossil woods characteristics,rock-layer facies and sedimentary environment,we consider that they are adult trees growing near the bank of river,and spacing in the rows ranging from 3～8 meters,which formed the good plant communities with a certain spatial structure.Then,the uplift of the vicinal mountains and the development of arid climate in this area,the plants were buried and the metasomatism with plaster took place,and then formed the calcium sulfate fossil woods,which could show the climate deteriorated in the region since the early-Miocene.

NkbJgTBN.title: Magnetostratigraphy of Cenozoic sediments from the Xining Basin: Tectonic implications for the northeastern Tibetan Plateau
NkbJgTBN.abstract: The Xining subbasin of the Longzhong basin holds the longest continuous Cenozoic stratigraphic record at the margin of the northeastern Tibetan Plateau. Despite a rich biostratigraphic content (including the Xiejia mammal fauna), the tectonic evolution of the basin is largely unconstrained. In this study we present stratigraphic, biostratigraphic, and magnetostratigraphic results that provide a basis for reconstructing the Cenozoic tectonic evolution of the Xining basin with respect to adjacent regions of the northeastern Tibetan Plateau. Magnetostratigraphic analysis from three red bed sections in the Xining basin indicates continuous deposition at low and nearly constant accumulation rates (average 2.2 cm/kyr) from 52.0 to 17.0 Ma. We interpret this result to indicate that no major regional tectonic event implying large sediment accumulation variations has affected the Xining basin deposition during this considerable time window. In detail, accumulation rate variations outline a three-stage evolution with 1.8 cm/kyr from 52.0 Ma to 34.5 Ma, 4.1 cm/kyr from 34.5 to 31.0 Ma, and 2.3 cm/kyr from 31.0 to 17.0 Ma. The second-order increase between 34.5 and 31.0 Ma can be interpreted to result from either a distal tectonic event or to be of climatic origin. Although the region was tectonically quiescent for much of the Cenozoic, tectonic activity occurred during basin initiation (or reactivation) at circa 55.0–52.5 Ma and during intense basin deformation after 17.0 Ma.

k1xeAy1g.title: Surface-water freshening: A cause for the onset of North Pacific stratification from 2.75 Ma onward?
k1xeAy1g.abstract: Paleoceanographic data indicate a sudden stratification in the North Pacific Ocean around 2.75 Ma. Understanding the triggering mechanism for this sudden North Pacific stratification is one key to resolving forcing mechanisms for the Northern Hemisphere glaciation around 2.75 Ma, one of the most perplexing problems in paleoclimate research. The trigger for this sudden stratification has not been fully explored. Changes in deep-water or surface-water temperature and/or salinity can cause stratification. Here we re-examine paleoceanography data from the North Pacific Ocean and find evidence that the stratification was preceded by a surface-water salinity decrease between 2.83 and 2.75 Ma. This paleoceanographic result, in combination with recent model simulation results, suggests that fresh water input to the North Pacific via an intensified East Asian summer monsoon and/or an intensified Polar Westerly winter jet stream associated with a phase of accelerated uplift of the northeastern Tibetan Plateau from 4–2.6 Ma might be one important forcing for the onset of North Pacific stratification. Onset of North Pacific stratification around 2.75 Ma is closely related to the intensification of Northern Hemisphere glaciation around the same time via its effects on atmospheric CO 2 concentration and sea surface temperature seasonality. Forcing the onset of the North Pacific stratification and Northern Hemisphere glaciation via surface-water freshening has not been emphasized previously.

LiLWx9gF.title: Research Progress of 5-Aminopyrazole Pesticides
LiLWx9gF.abstract: In this paper,research progress of 5-aminopyrazole pesticides is reviwed.Fipronil is the representative varieties of5-aminopyrazole pesticides.A lot of highly active fipronil analogues were researched on the basis of fipronil,in which some have insecticidal activity,while some have the activity of plant growth regulator.Others have both insecticidal activity and bactericidal activity.

Flfe6jan.title: Recycling and reuse of brominated flame-retardant plastics
Flfe6jan.abstract: The recovery of brominated flame-retardant plastics is basically the recovery of the electric and electronic equipment made from this kind of plastics.Three methods for recycling and reuse of brominated flame-retarded plastics are summarized.①Mechanical recycling;②Incineration with energy recovery;③Incineration of pyrolysis with recovery of bromine or hydrobromic acid.The discussions focus on the environmental issue in the recycling processes.From the ecological and economical points of view,both the mechanical and incineration methods are practical and safe.But the incineration process should be carried out properly and the production and release of dioxins must be strictly controlled and monitored.

b6aKyaoH.title: Middle Miocene to earliest Pliocene sedimentological and geochemical records of climate change in the western Qaidam Basin on the NE Tibetan Plateau
b6aKyaoH.abstract: Global cooling, Tibetan Plateau uplift and the retreat of the Para-Tethys Sea have long been thought to be the key controls of the Cenozoic climate change in the Asian inland. However, due to the scarcity of long-term palaeoclimate records, it is not entirely clear which of these factors plays the major role. Here, we present new sedimentological and geochemical proxy records (TOC, carbonate, SO4 2- and Cl-) from a 1040m late Cenozoic sedimentary sequence (ca. 17 to 5.0Ma) from the western part of the Qaidam Basin, the largest inland basin on the NE Tibetan Plateau. Geochemical records reveal an evident two-stage change. From ca. 17Ma to 11.1Ma (Phase I), the proxies show an upward decrease of carbonate content and TOC concentration and a persistent increase in the concentration of the soluble anions SO4 2- and Cl-, even though superimposed high-frequency fluctuations are evident. From ca. 11.1Ma to 5.0Ma (Phase II), the average concentrations of SO4 2- and Cl- are higher than those from Phase I, and a sharp decrease in the carbonate content occurred.The sedimentological and geochemical proxy records demonstrate that the Qaidam Basin has experienced increased aridity since ca. 11.1. Ma. We suggest that the Miocene global cooling exerted a significant influence on the drying of the Qaidam Basin by decreasing evaporation rates and water vapour concentrations in the atmosphere. The Mio-Pliocene episodic and persistent uplift of the NE Tibetan Plateau exerted an important influence superimposed upon this driving force, while during ca. 11.1 to 8. Ma, the rapid uplift of the Altun Shan might have played a key role in climate change of the Qaidam Basin. ? 2013 Elsevier B.V.

CyUjMm6O.title: Magneteostratigraphy of Yumen Conglomerate in the Yumushan Region and Its Implication for Deformation and Uplift of the NE Tibetan Plateau
CyUjMm6O.abstract: The Cenozoic deformation and uplift of the Tibetan Plateau is a hot issue in recent study of earth science.The Yumu Shan,located in the northeastern margin of the Qilian Shan,northeast Tibetan Plateau,is the key area for deciphering the spatio-temporal evolution of the entire plateau.The thick molasse(Yumen conglomerate) deposited in the Yumushan region,with bottom age of ~3.58 Ma by the magneteostratigraphy.Based on the paleocurrents,magnetic susceptibility,field research and published results,the Yumen conglomerate was likely the product of tectonic uplifting,and three unconformities related to the Yumen conglomerate were developed with age ranging from 5.23~3.58,2.88~2.58,and <~1.77~0.8Ma,respectively.Integrated study suggests that the uplift and deformation of the Yumushan region was not later than 3.58 Ma,experiencing at least two successive tectonics events.Our result is one Ma earlier than time of deformation and uplift,which was inferred from northward growth model of the Tibetan Plateau,and should be part response of Qingzang-Kunhuang Movement in the northeastern part of the plateau.
keywords: deformation and uplift of the Tibetan Plateau

kqkBh2Nh.title: Synthesis and properties of degradable elastomer poly[(propanediol-sebacate-citrate]
kqkBh2Nh.abstract: Intermidiate 1,2-propanediol-sebacate was synthesized with 1,2-propanediol and sebacic acid,then a novel degradable elastomer,poly[(propanediol-sebacate)-citrate](PPSC),was synthesized by melt phase polycondensation of 1,2-propanediol-sebacate and citric acid under under certain conditions.Effect of type of catalyst and water-carrying agent,mole ratio of sebacic acid to 1,2-propanediol on the synthesis of intermidiate were investigated,and the intermidiate and PPSC were characterized.The mechanical properties and in vitro degradation of PPSC were primarily studied.The results showed that intermidiate 1,2-propanediol-sebacate of low relative molecular mass was synthesized with toluene-p-sulfoinc acid as catalyst,benzene as water-carrying agent,and of mole ratio of sebacic acid to 1,2-propanediol of 1∶ 4.The glass-transition temperatures of PPSC were below 0 ℃ which confirmed that PPSC would be in a high-elastic state of ambient temperature and human body temperature.PPSC was a elastomer with moderate crosslinkage,low module and high elongation,and had rapid degradation ratio(degradation degree more than 50%) in phosphate(pH value 7.4) at 37 ℃.

azyoS1ZF.title: Preparation of multi-walled carbon nanotubes/poly(ether amine) composite
azyoS1ZF.abstract: Pyrene labeled poly(ether amine),pePEA in short,was synthesized via step-by-step nucleophilic addition polymerization.Resultant polymer was used to modify multi-walled carbon nanotube(MWNT) via non-covalent functionalization.The microstructure of as-prepared MWNT/pePEA composite was analyzed using a transmission electron microscope,and the content of pePEA in the composite was determined by thermogravimetric analysis.It has been found that pePEA is able to well enwrap MWNT forming an enwrapping layer of 1 nm thick,while the content of pePEA in the composite is 20.4%(mass fraction).In the meantime,as-prepared MWNT/pePEA composite can be well dispersed in water,and its aqueous dispersion is free of segregation and agglomeration after three week of storage,showing good stability.

zsQ5XG5t.title: Exploring Quaternary paleolake evolution and climate change in the western Qaidam Basin based on the bulk carbonate geochemistry of lake sediments
zsQ5XG5t.abstract: Abstract   This study focuses on the concentration of major and trace elements in the diluted acetic acid-soluble fraction of SG-1 core lacustrine sediments from the western Qaidam Basin (Tibetan Plateau) in order to explore the potential of applying bulk carbonate analysis to tracing paleolake evolution and climate change. The SG-1 core sediments are considered highly suited to the exploration of the paleoenvironmental significance of bulk carbonate geochemistry, because most carbonates in the core are authigenic in origin. Based on a principal component analysis of the elemental composition of diluted acetic acid leachate, four major components with distinct characteristics have been extracted, accounting for ~ 80% of the total variance. The first and most important component is associated with a high positive loading of Mn, P, Y, Sc and rare earth elements (REE); the second component is characterized by a high positive loading of Ca, Sr, and U; the third component displays a high negative loading of Mg, Li, and B; and the fourth component is associated with a relatively high positive loading of Fe, V and Cr. After considering the geochemical behavior of these element assemblies during acid leaching, we have concluded that these four components contain information indicative of watershed climate conditions, carbonate precipitation, lake water salinity and iron oxide content, respectively. Reconstructions of watershed climate change and paleolake evolution using the component scores are comparable to those reconstructed from other independent proxy records, indicating a long-term trend of lake shrinkage and climatic drying since ~ 2.7 Ma with abrupt drying events at ~ 2.5 Ma, ~ 1.8 Ma, ~ 1.2 Ma and ~ 0.6 Ma. Our results suggest that lake carbonates bear more information about watershed climate and lake evolution than expected, and that occurrences of some elements, in particular trace elements, in the diluted acetic acid leachate are not solely and necessarily linked to carbonate minerals.

vcilIQo9.title: Graphenol defects induced blue emission enhancement in chemically reduced graphene quantum dots
vcilIQo9.abstract: In this work, few layer graphene quantum dots (GQDs) with a size of 3-5 nm are purposely treated with highly concentrated aqueous NaBH4 solutions to obtain the reduced graphene quantum dots (rGQDs). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Raman spectroscopy demonstrate that the number of carbonyl groups decreases but -OH related defects increase during chemical reduction. Green and weak emissions of original GQDs originate from carrier recombination in the disorder-induced localized state (mainly including carbonyl and carboxyl and epoxy groups). As the reduction degree increases, the photoluminescence (PL) quantum efficiency of GQDs increases dramatically from 2.6% to 10.1%. In the meantime, the PL peak position blue shifts rapidly, and full width at half maximum (FWHM) becomes narrower. Thus we can infer that graphenol topological defects (hydroxyl functionalized graphene) are gradually formed during reduction. Besides, graphenol defect related PL features a longer fluorescence lifetime, excitation wavelength dependence but less pH sensitivity.

hoA23CUk.title: Research Progress of Pyrazolopyrimidine Pesticides
hoA23CUk.abstract: In this paper,research progress of pyrazolopyrimidine pesticides was reviwed.They are classified as pyrazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidine and pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidine according to the different structure features.Most of pyrazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidine compounds have fungicidal activity,some of them have herbicidal or insecticidal activity.Whereas the majority of pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidines have herbicidal activity,some show fungicidal or nematicidal activity.

29mXOoKg.title: Distribution of lipids in modern soils from various regions with continuous climate (moisture-heat) change in China and their climate significance
29mXOoKg.abstract:
Total 26 modern soil samples were collected from various regions under different climate conditions from tropical to arid
 temperate in China and systematically analyzed for their organic matters by GC/MS in order to evaluate climatic impacts on
 soil organic components. Abundant lipids molecules were recognized, including n-alkanes, n-alkenones, and long-chain branched
 alkanes. We find the predominance of main peaks of long-chain n-alkanes (nC29, nC31, nC33) and short-chain ones (nC16, nC17, nC18) records information of soil generation in warm-humid and cold-dry regions. The proportion of n-alkanes (nC16+nC17+nC18) to (nC29+nC31+nC33) varies in good agreement with moisture-heat conditions and thus probably can serve as a new index for climate change. The
 ratios of C21
 −/nC22
 +, nC17/nC31 and (nC15+nC17+nC19) / (nC27 + nC29 + nC31) of n-alkanes, indicating respectively input ratios of lower bacterial alga, aquatic organisms, and higher plants and terraneous
 organisms, co-vary well in different climate regions from forest to grassland and desert, suggesting that they have also reflected
 the difference of climates between monsoon region and inland one. The C21
 −/C22
 + ratio of n-alkan-2-one records largely the discrepancy of temperature from north to south of China bordered by the Qinling
 Mountains, but less humidity. The C21
 −/C22
 + ratio of n-alkan-3-ones changes well with climatic factors, such as temperature and humidity. The biogenic source of series
 A-D long-chain branched alkanes may be derived from some kinds of special epiphyte that most likely live in weak oxic-anoxic
 and moisture-heat environments, suggesting their distribution record as well some information on climatic change. All these
 researches demonstrate that the distributions of lipids molecules in modern soils in China record well signals of climates
 from quite different climatic regions, and can serve as important climatic proxies to reveal climatic change over China.

iJ0GZSCd.title: A 60 000-year loess-paleosol record of millennial-scale summer monsoon instability from Lanzhou, China
iJ0GZSCd.abstract: The 28-m high-resolution Shajinping loess section in Lanzhou on the Chinese western Loess Plateau records a detailed history of millennial Asian summer monsoon change since the earlier last glaciation. Summer monsoon proxies of soil magnetic susceptibility, carbonate content and soil color show that Asian summer monsoon experienced a series of rapid episodic pulse enhancements spanning only ca. 1-2 ka and have sub-Milankovitch cycles of progressive weakening in low frequency domain since ca. 60 kaBP. Soil formation responds to these by deepening colors, accumulating organic matter, increasing biological channels and leaching certain carbonates. The pedogenic degree generally increases with the degree of enhancement of summer monsoon. These may reflect the impact of the last glacial fast climatic change in the North Atlantic region on Asian summer monsoon.

LxiXkP4G.title: Palaeoenvironmental and chronological constraints on the Early Pleistocene mammal fauna from loess deposits in the Linxia Basin, NE Tibetan Plateau
LxiXkP4G.abstract: Abstract   The Longdan mammal fauna from the central part of Linxia Basin, NE Tibetan Plateau, is the first Early Pleistocene fauna in China in which the fossils are derived loess deposits, and it provides an excellent opportunity to document mammalian and environmental evolution in Asia. However, the precise age and palaeoenvironmental setting of the fauna are controversial due to the poor exposure of the outcrop section. In the present study, a 105-m-long drill core was obtained from Longdan village and used for detailed magnetostratigraphic dating. The results demonstrate that the late Pliocene- Pleistocene loess deposits in the Longdan section deposited since ca. 3 Ma and that the Longdan fauna has an age range of 2.5–2.2 Ma. In addition, the results of lithological and rock magnetic analyses demonstrate that paleosols are weakly developed throughout the whole core and that in the lower and middle parts the core the magnetic susceptibility and its frequency dependence are relatively low and uniform. These observations, combined with the ecological characteristics of the Longdan fauna, indicate that during the Early Pleistocene the climate in the Longdan area, and even in the Linxia Basin, was sub-humid and that the aeolian dust was frequently subjected to post-depositional reworking by water.

i6qKdZ07.title: Magnetostratigraphy study on the miocene sediments of suerkal basin, altyn tagh and its significance
i6qKdZ07.abstract: The Altyn Tagh fault is the northernmost controlling boundary of the Tibetan Plateau, which plays an important role in growth of the Tibetan Plateau. We carried out integrated research on Cenozoic stratigraphic sections in the intermontane basin of the Alty Tagh. Existing biostratigraphic data, and magnetostratigraphic analysis were used to establish chronostratigraphy, whereas composition of sandstone and coarse clastic sedimentary rocks was used to determine the unlift history of the source region. Much of the detrital grains in our measured sections can be correlated with uplifted of the surrounding mountains, implying a temporal link between sedimentation and deformation. The results of our studies, together with existing uplift period of the Kunlun Mountains, suggest that uplifting events started about 18Ma in northern Tibet. © 2005 IEEE.

K65ARKa3.title: A preliminary reconstruction of the paleoecological and paleoclimatic history of the Chinese Loess Plateau from the application of biomarkers
K65ARKa3.abstract: This study provides a preliminary reconstruction of paleoecological and paleoclimatic history over the central Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP) during the last 8.1 Ma based on biomarker records from the earliest of the Chaona stratigraphic section. Throughout the section, we found variations in n -alkane and n -alkan-2-one distributions and dramatic changes in six other biomarker proxies: 1) n -alkanes (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios, 2) n -alkanes C 27 /C 31 ratios, 3) CPI (carbon preference index) values for CPI (H) ALK, 4) values for CPI (H) KET, 5) n -alkane mean chain lengths ACL-ALK, and 6) n -alkan-2-ones C 29 /C 31 ratios. The C 29 n -alkanes dominate the red clay sediments with little variability, indicating that trees dominated the CLP and that the climate was relatively stable and less variable during the 8.1–2.6 Ma period. In contrast, the C 31 n -alkanes dominate the loess–paleosol sediments, and biomarkers vary with relatively greater amplitude and higher frequency, indicating that grasses dominated the CLP and the climate was more arid and variable. These biomarker records chronicle a drying and cooling trend on the CLP since 4 Ma. These records can be further divided into four stages with boundaries around 5.6, 3.8 and 2.6 Ma, indicating that the CLP vegetation and climate experienced four evolutionary phases, broadly consistent with those inferred from other available proxy data. Keywords Loess–paleosol sequences Red-clay Biomarker Chinese Loess Plateau Asian drying 1 Introduction A clearer understanding of the climatic forcing mechanisms of the Asian drying and Asian monsoon will cast light on possible future climate changes. Consequently, the forcing mechanisms for the evolution of the Asian monsoon have attracted increasing attention from scientists and the public. The loess–paleosol and red-clay sequences on the CLP have been widely accepted as a valid geologic archive for documenting the history and variability of the East Asian monsoon and related climate (e.g., Liu, 1985; An et al., 1990; Ding et al., 1998; An et al., 1999, 2000; Guo et al., 2001, 2002; Miao et al., 2004; Vandenberghe et al., 2004 ); however, a number of issues remain unresolved. Recent studies indicate that the Asian desertification began around 22 Ma ( Guo et al., 2001 ), accelerated first between ~ 8 and ~ 7 Ma, and again between ~ 3.6 and ~ 2.6 Ma ( Li and Fang, 1999; An et al., 2000, 2001; Sun and An, 2002; Nie et al., 2007, 2008a,b ). However, different opinions exist about the timing, mostly because of questions about the validity of magnetic susceptibility and grain size as proxies for paleo-monsoonal changes or desertification ( An et al., 1991; Ding and Liu, 1992; Ding et al., 2001; Han et al., 2002; Nie et al., 2007, 2008a,b ). Thus, independent organic proxies are needed to help resolve these debates. Reconstructing paleo-environments using organic compounds constitutes a major field in the application of organic geochemistry. Although biomarkers have been shown to be valid climate proxies on the CLP, studies so far have largely been limited to the last 170 ka ( Yan et al., 1998; Peng and Jia, 2001; Xie et al., 2002, 2003; Wang et al., 2004; Zhang et al., 2006 ). Here we present preliminary organic geochemical data for the last 8 Ma from the well-studied Chaona stratigraphic section (107°12′ E, 35°6′ N) on the central CLP ( Song et al., 2000; Lü et al., 2001; Wu et al., 2004; Ma et al., 2005; Wu et al., 2007; Chen et al., 2007; Nie et al., 2007, 2008a,b,c ). This paper discusses the broad paleoclimate and the paleo-vegetation history of the CLP over the last 8 Ma based on n -alkane and n -alkan-2-one distributions and six other biomarker proxies: 1) n -alkanes (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios, 2) n -alkanes C 27 /C 31 ratios, 3) CPI (carbon preference index) values for CPI (H) ALK, 4) values for CPI (H) KET, 5) n -alkane mean chain lengths ACL-ALK, and 6) n -alkan-2-ones C 29 /C 31 ratios. 2 Samples and methods 2.1 Introduction to the study area and the study section The study area lies near the town of Chaona on the central CLP. The present summer climate of the study area is warm and humid and the winter climate is cold and dry. The average annual temperature and precipitation are 8–9 °C and 550 mm, respectively ( Fig. 1 ). The area presently maintains warm-temperate forest steppe vegetation, characterized by Quercus liaotungensis , Pinus tabulaeformis , Stipa bungeana , Artemisia giraldii and Bothriochloa ischaemum ( Hou, 1994 ). The entire study section is about 300 m thick; the upper 175 m comprises the loess–paleosol sequence and the lower 125 m contains the red-clay sequence. The Quaternary loess–paleosol sequences consist of 32 paleosols (S) and 33 loess (L) layers. Lü et al. (2001) has established an age model for the Chaona section, based on control point ages (top and basal ages of astronomically-tuned paleosols from sequences S 1 to S 32 for the loess–paleosol sequence, and paleomagnetic reversal ages for the red-clay sequence). Magneto-stratigraphic studies indicate that the red clay started to accumulate around 8.1 Ma at the section studied ( Song et al., 2000 ). The red clay sequence can be divided lithologically into five units (Red clay (RC)-1 to RC-5; Fig. 2 ). The first unit (RC-1) is generally brownish red, with well-developed pedogenesis; the second unit (RC-2) is relatively weakly developed with a light brownish red color; the third unit (RC-3) is the reddest of the entire red clay deposits, with strong pedogenesis; the fourth unit (RC-4) is composed of light brownish red soils; and the fifth unit is yellowish brown in color with weak pedogenesis. 2.2 Sampling and analytic methods Six paleosol (SZ-1, SZ-3 to SZ-6, SZ-9), three loess (SZ-2, SZ-7 and SZ-8), and ten red clay samples (CN-1 to CN-10) were selected for organic geochemical analyses (stratigraphic positions, ages and sequences shown in Fig. 2 and Table 1 ). An aliquot (~ 20 g) of each sample was Soxhlet-extracted with chloroform for 56 h. Total organic carbon (TOC) concentrations range from 0.03 to 0.39% in the Chaona section ( Table 1 ). To minimize loss, we did not separate the extracted organic matter (OM) into compound classes and the extracts were directly analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). A blank was analyzed to monitor for contamination. Organic solvents were doubly distilled. Filter papers were Soxhlet-extracted with dichloromethane (DCM) prior to use. GC-MS analyses were performed using a Hewlett-Packard (HP) 5973 mass spectrometer in electron ionization mode (E 70 eV) interfaced directly with a HP-6890 GC equipped with a HP-5MS fused silica capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm i.d; 0.25 μm film thickness). The GC oven temperature was ramped upward from 80 to 300 °C at 5 °C/min and held at 280 °C for 20 min. Helium was used as a carrier gas. 3 Results 3.1 Distribution of aliphatic hydrocarbons, alkanones, and wax esters Our study found a variety of lipids in the Chaona sedimentary sequences; and reports here the distributions of C 15 –C 33 n -alkanes, isoprenoid alkanes, C 16 –C 33 n -alkan-2-ones, and C 28 –C 36 wax esters. The molecular distributions of these lipids can be used to infer paleo-vegetation, paleoclimate, and paleo-bacteria activity information. Organic matter on the CLP could be produced in situ or transported by wind. Although Liu et al. (2007) argue that the isotopic composition of loess' TOC in arid areas is largely controlled by the carbon isotope composition of the dust source (with only a minor contribution from local native vegetation), the dust source regions (i.e., the Gobi and the northwestern deserts) are very dry and exhibit low plant productivity. Thus we expect a low content of lipids ( Zhang et al., 2006 ). Based on this, we argue that the distribution of the n -alkanes in this section results mainly from: 1) microorganisms (algae, cyanobacteria, fungi and other bacteria), and 2) higher plants growing in situ . 3.1.1 Aliphatic hydrocarbons The aliphatic hydrocarbon fraction consists mainly of n -alkanes and isoprenoid alkanes (pristane and phytane, Pr/Ph ratios varying from 0.17 to 0.89; Table 1 ). Straight chain alkanes represent the most abundant hydrocarbons in the extracts. Fig. 2 shows the distributions of n -alkanes from different units. The lower molecular weight n -alkanes, dominated by the C 18 homologue are believed to come from microorganisms (algae, cyanobacteria, fungi and other bacteria; e.g., Freeman and Colarusso, 2001; Xie et al., 2002, 2003 ). The C 29 n -alkanes have been reported to come from deciduous trees ( Cranwell, 1973 ) and C 31 or C 33 n -alkanes have been proposed to come from grasses ( Cranwell et al., 1987; Meyers and Ishiwatari, 1993; Xie et al., 2002; Wang et al., 2004; Zhang et al., 2006 ). Hence, n -alkane distribution patterns have been used to estimate changes in vegetation type and thus paleoclimate. Above C 22 , we observe a distinct odd-over-even carbon number predominance. The long-chain n -alkanes (above C 22 ) are characterized by a rather invariant distribution pattern with a C 29 dominance within the red clay sequence. In contrast, C 31 dominates within the loess–paleosol sequence, except in paleosol samples SZ-5 (corresponding to sequence S8) and SZ-9 (S28), which are dominated by the C 29 n -alkane in the high-molecular-weight (HMW) range. Previous studies on the CLP have also reported the loess-paleosol n -alkanes to be characterized by a rather invariant distribution pattern with C 31 dominance, indicating a predominance of grasslands over the CLP ( Xie et al., 2002; Wang et al., 2004; Zhang et al., 2006 ). Our results not only confirm that grasses dominate the CLP during the last 2.6 Ma, but they also indicate that deciduous trees dominate the CLP between 8.1 and 2.6 Ma. 3.1.2 Alkanones A series of n -alkan-2-ones, ranging from C 16 to C 33 ( Fig. 2 ), were also detected. C 29 dominates these n -alkan-2-ones except in samples SZ-4, SZ-9, CN-3, and CN-4 (stratigraphic positions shown in Fig. 2 ), where C 27 dominates. The n -alkan-2-ones are commonly observed lipid components of paleosols from the CLP ( Xie et al., 2002, 2003; Wang et al., 2004 ). They are thought to originate either from microbiological sub-terminal oxidation of n -alkanes or from β-oxidation of fatty acids, followed by decarboxylation. Dominance of the C 29 homologue in both the HMW n -alkanes and n -alkan-2-ones throughout the red clay sediments favors the oxidation of n -alkanes pathway. In contrast, the dominance of the C 31 homologue in HMW n -alkanes and C 29 in HMW n -alkan-2-ones within the loess–paleosol sequence, suggests that fatty acids could be the source for n -alkan-2-ones. CPI (H) -KET and CPI (H) -ALK correlate positively in the red clay sequence and negatively in the loess–paleosols sequence ( Fig. 3 ). These relationships with CPI (H) ALK and CPI (H) KET may indicate that n -alkan-2-one sources cannot be explained solely by microbial oxidation of n -alkanes in the red clay and from β-oxidation of fatty acids followed by decarboxylation in the loess–paleosol layers ( Figs. 2 and 3 ). Alternative sources or direct input of epicuticular waxes from higher plants may have played a role ( Quénéa et al., 2004 ). This topic merits further investigation. 3.1.3 Wax esters Our analyses found wax esters, ranging mainly from C 28 to C 36 (total number of carbon atoms in the compound) at relatively low concentrations, and we did not use these to estimate vegetation and climate changes on the CLP. Alkanoic acid moieties ranged from C 14 to C 16 and n -alkanols from C 12 to C 21 , with common combinations of acid to alcohol moieties of C 14 to C 18 , and C 16 to C 18 , C 16:1 to C 14 , C 16:1 to C 16 and C 16:1 to C 18 predominating ( Fig. 4 ). Although the results differ from those previously reported from terrestrial higher plants (in the range C 36 –C 50 ; e.g., Rieley et al., 1991; Ficken et al., 1998 ), we have found similar results in modern Chinese soil samples ( Bai et al., 2006 ). 3.2 Time series of n-alkanes (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ), C 27 /C 31 , CPI (H) ALK and CPI (H) KET, ACL-ALK, and n -alkan-2-ones C 29 /C 31 The Chaona section provides six lipid biomarker proxies used to infer the evolution of the East Asian monsoon on the central CLP. 3.2.1 CPI (H) ALK, CPI (H) KET values and n -alkan-2-ones C 29 /C 31 Biomarkers from different biological origins provide different CPI values ( Cranwell et al., 1987 ), and these are affected by microbial activities, such as sedimentary reworking and diagenesis. Because the rates of degradation and alteration differ under different climatic conditions, the CPI values of paleo-lipids can thereby reflect the paleoclimate. Many studies have proposed that degradation of micro-organisms can reduce CPI values of HMW n -alkyl-lipids in soils ( Huang et al., 1996; Bull et al., 2000; Freeman and Colarusso, 2001; Xie et al., 2003, 2004 ). Under a cold, dry climate, microbial activity is low ( Kuder and Kruge, 1998 ) and thus such conditions tend to yield high CPI values ( Xie et al., 2004 ). In contrast, lower CPI values tend to result from accelerated microbial activity associated with a warm and wet climate ( Zhou et al., 2005 ). This proposal has been further confirmed by Bai et al. (2006) from modern soils in China. The CPI (H) ALK values vary from 0.89 to 6.06 and gradually decrease with increasing depth ( Fig. 5 B, see formula in Fig. 5 ). The highest CPI (H) ALK values (corresponding to sequence L26) may result from increased preservation of organic matter associated with a dry and cool climate. The CPI (H) KET values vary between 0.87 and 5.44, but do not decrease with increasing depth as do CPI (H) ALK values. This proxy's lowest values come from samples CN-4 to CN-6, which correspond to incorporate warm and wet time interval, similar to CPI (H) ALK ( Fig. 5 A). The CPI (H) -KET values and C 29 /C 31 KET ratios display some similarities throughout the profile, with minimum values in the red clay samples CN-4 and CN-5 ( Fig. 5 A). Xie et al. (2003) also observed the co-variation between the CPI (H) -KET values and C 29 /C 31 KET ratios in the Jiuzhoutai loess–paleosol sequences, Lanzhou, northwest China. These two proxies display a distinct correlation with magnetic susceptibility in the Jiuzhoutai section, and these correlations have been proposed to result from the varying levels of micro-organism activity in paleosol (loess) layers associated with the strength of the East Asian summer monsoon ( Xie et al., 2003 ). The CPI (H) ALK abnormity in sample SZ-4 (corresponding to sequence S5) probably results from increased abundances of the mid-chain length C 23 and C 25 n -alkanes. 3.2.2 Significance of n-alkane ACL values ACL values indicate the concentration-weighted mean chain length of the C 27 to C 33 n -alkanes present in a sample, and have historically been explained by differences in growing-season temperatures in the source regions ( Poynter et al., 1989 ). Plants in warmer/wetter areas have higher ACL values than those in colder/drier areas ( Zhou et al., 2005 ). The n -alkane ACL values from the Chaona section decrease with increasing depth, similar to CPI （H） ALK values. These increase from 29.3 to 30.4 with some oscillations in the loess–paleosol sequence, possibly caused by an increase in grasses, which produce large proportions of the C 31 n -alkane. The n -alkane ACL values vary from 28.9 to 29.8 in the red clay, with minimum values between CN-4 (3.96 Ma) and CN-6 (5.48 Ma), characterized by the development of woody plants ( Cranwell, 1973 ; Fig. 5 B). The values in the loess–paleosol sequence are generally similar to those at Xunyi and Luochuan (ACL values from 30.1 to 30.8 and 29.9 to 30.6, respectively) during the last 170 kyr ( Zhang et al., 2006 ). ACL values co-vary with CPI (H) ALK. They stay generally high during the loess–paleosol sequence, and reach minimum values near the level of sample SZ-9 (2.1 Ma, S28). Within the red clay sequence, the ACL values were ~ 29.5 during the time period represented by samples CN-10 to CN-8, then began to decrease at the time of CN-7 and reached minimum values in samples CN-6 to CN-4. The increasing-upward trends of the CPI (H) ALK and n -alkane ACL proxies from sample SZ-9 to the overlying Quaternary sediments suggest that the climate gradually became cooler in northwest China, resulting in grassland development and continued aridity. A similar pattern is also observed at Xunyi during the last 170 kyr ( Zhang et al., 2006 ). 3.2.3 The n -alkane C 27 /C 31 and (C 27 + C 29 ) /(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios Woody plants display n -alkane distributions dominated by C 27 or C 29 n -alkanes, whereas grasses produce distributions dominated by the C 31 n -alkane ( Cranwell, 1973; Meyers and Ishiwatari, 1993 ). Hence, n -alkane distribution patterns can be used to estimate changes in vegetation types ( Schwark et al., 2002; Rommerskirchen et al., 2003; Xie et al., 2002, 2003; Liang et al., 2005 ). Fig. 6 shows a ternary diagram for the same three n -alkanes (C 27 , C 29 and C 31 ) in the Chaona section, with two recognizable clusters of sites. The red clay cluster (samples CN-1-10, SZ-4 and SZ-9) plots close to the region that characterizes equatorial rain forests ( Schwark et al., 2002; Rommerskirchen et al., 2003 ). The loess and paleosol clusters plot near the position characterized by the deserts and savannah grasslands in Southwest Africa and CLP dominated by grasses over the last 170 kyr ( Schwark et al., 2002; Rommerskirchen et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2006 ). This difference can best be explained in terms of vegetation, that is, grasses dominate the loess–paleosols with some increase in trees during the warm stages, especially SZ-4 (S5) and SZ-9 (S28), and deciduous trees dominate during deposition of the red clay. In the Chaona section, the C 27 /C 31 and (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratio curves essentially parallel each other, with higher values in the red clay, especially between CN-4 to CN-6, suggesting the prevalence of deciduous trees between 5.6 and 3.86 Ma. The decreasing trends of these ratios upward from sample CN-4 to the overlying Quaternary sediments indicate gradual development of grasslands after 3.8 Ma ( Fig. 5 C), probably due to gradually cooling temperatures, which caused continued aridity over the CLP. In summary, these proxies correlate well with each other ( Fig. 5 ), which further suggests that climate, rather than local factors, provided the drivers for their variations. 4 Discussion and conclusions 4.1 Cooling and drying trends on the CLP since 4 Ma Increasing ACL-ALK values and decreasing C 27 /C 31 and (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios after 4 Ma indicate that the CLP experienced cooling and drying (greater seasonality of precipitation) trends, respectively. These cooling and drying trends on the CLP are especially apparent during the 4–2.6 Ma interval. Dramatic cooling and drying on the CLP starting from 4 Ma coincide with many lines of evidence that indicate Tibetan uplift ( Nie et al., 2008a,b ), but precede the Northern Hemisphere cryosphere expansions around 3.6 Ma ( Mudelsee and Raymo, 2005 ). Therefore, the rapid uplift of the Tibetan Plateau may have triggered the dramatic cooling and drying on the CLP. This explanation agrees with model simulations by An et al. (2001) . In contrast, the cooling and drying on the CLP after 2.6 Ma could have been paced by the expanding Northern Hemisphere cryosphere, as evidenced by increasingly positive glacial benthic oxygen isotope values. 4.2 Four evolutionary phases of paleoclimate and paleo-vegetation on the CLP within the last 8 Ma From 8.1 to 2.6 Ma, C 29 n -alkanes dominate the red clay sediments, suggesting a predominance of deciduous trees over the CLP. During the last 2.6 Ma, the C 31 n -alkanes dominate the loess–paleosols, indicating a predominance of grasses over the CLP. Biomarker variations from the loess–paleosol interval exhibit relatively large amplitude and high frequency, suggesting that last 2.6 Ma was a period of unstable climate with great variability in the winter monsoon strength, as well as the presence of more grasses, Conversely the records from the underlying red clay indicate relative stability ( Fig. 5 ), suggesting that the climate was relatively warm and wet, with smaller fluctuations. Fig. 5 illustrates the temporal variations from these records and previous studies, showing three marked ecological shifts at about 5.6, 3.8 and 2.6 Ma. In Phase 1 (~ 8.1 to 5.6 Ma, samples CN-7 to CN-10), n -alkane C 27 /C 31 and (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios are lower, but CPI (H) ALK, CPI (H) KET, and ACL-ALK values are higher, compared with Phase 2 (~ 5.6 to 3.8 Ma; see Table 1 for correlation of samples with Phase; Figs. 2 and 5 ). These data suggest a mixture of woodlands and grasslands on the CLP, with less rainfall and lower temperatures. The inferred paleoclimate and paleo-vegetation assessments coincide with 1) weaker soil development (as inferred from less scattered nodules, and yellowish brown soil color; Fig. 2 ), 2) the dry-plant pollen assemblages from those portions of the Chaona section ( Ma et al., 2005 ) and the nearby Lingtai section ( Wu, 2001 ), and 3) more positive benthic oxygen isotope values compared with Phase 2 ( Shackleton et al., 1995 , Ocean Drilling Program scientific results). Chloridion and carbonate studies from the Linxia Basin also indicate a very dry climate during Phase 1 ( Fang et al., 1997 ). In phase 2 (~ 5.6 to 3.8 Ma, red-clay samples CN-4 to CN-6), the lower CPI (H) KET, CPI (H) ALK and ACL-ALK values, together with the higher C 27 /C 31 and (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios ( Table 1 ; Figs. 2 and 5 ) imply a period dominated by woodlands, decreased seasonality of rainfall, and intensified microbial activity, which in combination suggests higher temperatures. The expansion of trees on the CLP around 5.6 Ma coincides with a warmer/lower ice volume climatic condition (Fig. 2 in Nie et al., 2008a,b,c ), which suggests that global climate modulates the monsoon and vegetation variations on the CLP. During the interval 4.5 to 4 Ma, Nie et al. (2008a,b,c) suggest that precipitation on the CLP was controlled by the Polar Westerlies, rather than the East Asian summer monsoon. Our data, which suggest a tree dominance during the latter stage of Phase 2 on the CLP (in spite of a colder climate indicated by more negative benthic oxygen isotopes), supports this Westerly rainfall source hypothesis. Paleoclimatic and paleo-vegetation conditions inferred from our biomarkers are consistent with many other available proxy data, such as highly-developed soil structures, less calcite content ( Chen et al., 2007 ), and wetter-plant pollen assemblages from the same section ( Ma et al., 2005 ). In Phase 3 (~ 3.8 to 2.6 Ma, red-clay samples CN-3~CN-1), n -alkane C 27 /C 31 and (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) ratios drop significantly compared to Phase 2; whereas CPI (H) ALK, CPI (H) KET, ACL-ALK and C 29 /C 31 KET values rise rapidly ( Figs. 2 and 5 ), indicating a cooler climate with increased seasonality of precipitation (a period of intensified winter and summer monsoons). These characteristics agree well with the pollen assemblage (3.71 to 2.58 Ma) from in this section ( Ma et al., 2005 ). In Phase 4 (~ 2.6 Ma to present), high CPI (H) ALK, CPI (H) KET and ACL-ALK values and low (C 27 + C 29 )/(C 31 + C 33 ) and C 27 /C 31 ratios ( Figs. 2 and 5 ) show the percentage of grasses on the CLP increasing and decreasing with some orbital-scale periodicity, indicating that the East Asian monsoon system is sensitive to ice sheets and insolation. Shifts in pollen assemblages from forest-steppe at 1.5 Ma to open-forest and steppe at 0.95 Ma and then to steppe at 0.5 Ma also indicate a stepwise drying of the CLP ( Wu et al., 2004, 2007 ). Systematic grain-size, paleomagnetic and geochemical measurements of the aeolian sediments in northwest China record these same transitions. These shifts appear directly related to the intensification of the East Asian paleo-monsoon during the Quaternary, probably associated with the uplift of Himalayan–Tibetan Plateau and Northern Hemisphere glaciations ( Fang et al., 1995, 1997; An et al., 2001; Chen et al., 2001; Sun, 2004 ). Given the lack of esterification and fractionation of our samples, we did not carry out a quantitative analysis of the fatty acid data. Measurements of n -alkanol and other lipid biomarkers (such as aromatic diterpenoids together with stable carbon isotopes) should provide additional tools for investigating lipid sources in this environment. We still lack detailed knowledge for many other special compounds in the Chaona section, limiting their value as specific environmental indicators. The long-term paleoclimatic and paleoecological history constructed from this study must be treated as tentative because of the coarse sampling interval. The sample resolution has been particularly limiting in determination of variation at the orbital scale. Substantially higher resolution studies and additional lipid marker proxies are required to elucidate details of climate and vegetation variability over the last 8.1 Ma. fF0vps7T.title: MICROMORPHOLOGY OF LATOSOLS IN HAINAN AND DIFFERENCES BETWEEN VEMICULATED RED SOILS AND LATOSOLS IN ENVIRONMENTAL SIGNIFICANCE IN SOUTH CHINA
fF0vps7T.abstract: Tropical soils with unique pedogenic processes influenced by warm humid climate are investigated worldwidely.Latosols are zonal soils in tropical areas of China and have been the subject for scientists studying mineralogical and geochemical characteristics.However studies on micromorphological characteristics of the soil are still far and rare.In this study,micromorphological features and pedogenic processes of three Latosol profiles derioedfrom different parent materials from Hainan Island are studied with soil micromorphological,clay mineralogical and chemical methods.Vermiculated red soils in South China,which were formed in the mid-Pleistocene,are called Latosols in some studies.To provide evidence for the study of palaeoenvironment and archaeology,vermiculated red soils are compared with Latosols in this study.The results indicate that Latosols mainly have two typical micromorphological features.One is the absence of unweatherable minerals and illuvial clay,and the other is the presence of nodules of iron and manganese oxides resulting from weathering and isotropic b-fabric in good drainage conditions.The typical pedogenic processes of latosols are strong weathering,rubification,homogenization,eluviation and remarkable desilication.In poor drainage conditions,some pseudogley features are formed.Resulting from strong chemical weathering under the tropical climate,Latosols are strongly developed.Compared with Latosols,vermiculated red soils are less developed.They cannot be classified as latosols and Oxisols,but tend to be classified as Ultisols in the American Soil Taxonomy,corresponding to red earths in the Chinese Soil Genetic Classification.This indicates wet,warm climate and indeciduous,latifoliate vegetation in the vast areas south of the Yangtze River during the forming period of vermiculated red soils.

oSMmeZKw.title: Origins of the Mid-Cretaceous evaporite deposits of the Sakhon Nakhon Basin in Laos: Evidence from the stable isotopes of halite
oSMmeZKw.abstract: Abstract   The origins of the evaporite deposits of the Khorat Plateau remain disputed. Based purely on the known evolution of the Khorat Plateau, materials of marine origin and/or remnant seawater should be present, but instead the salt layers of the deposits found there present typically continental lithological features. New data suggest that the Laotian evaporite deposits can be dated to the Middle to Late Cretaceous. In this paper we present the sulfate δ 34 S (5.2‰ to 15.6‰) and δ 18 O- SO4  (10.3‰ to 14.1‰) records, Sr isotopic compositions (0.707443 to 0.708587), δ 18 O -inclusion  (− 7.1‰ to 13.9‰) and δD -inclusion  (− 72‰ to − 150‰) records and the trace metal elements for halite deposits extracted from Core ZK2893 in the Sakhon Nakhon Basin, Laos. These values suggest that the deposits are of continental and hydrothermal origins with trace marine remnants. Evaporites in the basins are very likely to have been formed originally by the evaporation of seawater, prior to being dissolved in meteoric water and hydrothermal fluid, and subsequently precipitated.

Qqh3PwNv.title: Late Neogene magnetostratigraphy in the western Qaidam Basin (NE Tibetan Plateau) and its constraints on active tectonic uplift and progressive evolution of growth strata
Qqh3PwNv.abstract: The Qaidam Basin as the largest intermontane basin of the NE Tibetan Plateau is the ideal place to provide constraints on depositional and tectonic patters. To determine its tectonic deformation history and progressive evolution of growth strata we conducted paleomagnetic study on the late-Neogene stratigraphic section in the western Qaidam Basin. A magnetostratigraphic study of the well exposed 805. m Qigequan section at the Qigequan anticline in the western Qaidam Basin reveals twelve pairs of normal and reversed polarity zones which can be readily correlated with chrons C1n-3Ar of the Geomagnetic Polarity Time Scale (GPTS). From this correlation we can conclude that the Shizigou and the Qigequan formations were formed at > 6.9 Ma-2.5. Ma and 2.5-~ 0.4. Ma, respectively. Accumulation rates determined from our chronology, together with the occurrence of unconformities suggest four phases of tectonic uplift which began at about 3.6 Ma, 2.5 Ma, 1.1 Ma and 0.8 Ma. The results also suggest that offlap growth strata according to the limb rotation model on the anticlinorium started to occur at ~ 8.2. Ma. They progressively become younger from the frontal region of the Altyn Tagh Mts. (~ 8.2. Ma) to the southwestern basin (~ 2.5 Ma) and to further east of the Qaidam Basin (< 2.5 Ma), caused by fault-propagation-folding in the Qaidam Basin, rapid uplift and fast exhumation of the NE Tibetan Plateau at those times. © 2013 Elsevier B.V.
